DIVISION 6. - BOARD OF PLUMBING EXAMINERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; plumbing code, § 18-431 et seq.; plumbing and heating and cooling contractors, § 18-461 et seq. 
State Law reference- Board of plumbing examiners, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 18-1901-18-1909. 

Sec. 18-141. - Appointment; membership; board; term; officers; compensation; powers and duties; license. 
(a)  The board of plumbing examiners shall consist of not less than four members, at least one member to be known as the chief health officer of the city, one member to be known as the plumbing inspector of the city, one journeyman plumber, and one master plumber. The journeyman and master plumbers shall be appointed by the city manager. No member of the governing body shall serve as a member of the plumbing board. All vacancies in the board may be filled by the city manager as provided in this section. Any member of the board may be removed from office for cause by the district court of the county in which the city is situated. 
(b)  All members of the plumbing board shall be residents or live within the zoning jurisdiction of the city, and the plumbing inspector and journeyman and master plumbers shall be licensed plumbers. The governing body of the city may require that each member of the plumbing board give bond in the sum of $1,000.00, conditioned according to law, the cost of which may be paid by the city. 
(c)  The chief health officer and the plumbing inspector shall be appointed by and hold office during the term of office of the city manager. The terms of office of the journeyman plumber and the master plumber shall be for three years. Upon the expiration of the term of each appointed member, appointments shall be made for succeeding terms by the same process as the previous appointments. 
(d)  The board shall organize by the selection of one of their number as chairperson. The plumbing inspector shall be the secretary of the board. No member of the plumbing board shall serve in the capacity of both the chairperson and secretary of the board. It shall be the duty of the secretary to keep the full and correct minutes and records of all meetings and to file them with the city clerk where they shall be available for public inspection at any reasonable time. 
(e)  If the municipality has a chief health officer or health director and plumbing inspector, then they shall act as members of the plumbing board ex officio and shall receive no extra compensation. If there are no such officers in the city; then, on being appointed, they shall each receive as a salary an amount to be determined by resolution of the governing body. The members of the board who are not ex officio members shall be paid an amount to be determined by resolution of the governing body. 
(f)  The board shall be funded from time to time by the governing body out of the general fund. The board shall meet only upon call by the chairperson. Three members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of doing business. 
(g)  It shall be the duty of the board to adopt rules and regulations, not inconsistent with other city ordinances and state law, for the sanitary construction, alteration, and inspection of plumbing and sewerage connections and drains placed in, or in connection with, any and every building in the city. Such rules and regulations, except those that are adopted for the board's own convenience only, shall be approved by ordinance by the mayor and city council. Subject to the same approval requirements, the board shall have the power to amend or repeal its rules and regulations at any time. 
(h)  Any person desiring to do any plumbing or to work at the business of plumbing in the city shall make a written application to the plumbing board for an examination for a license. The board shall examine the applicant as to his practical and theoretical knowledge of plumbing, house drainage, ventilation, and sanitation. If the applicant shows himself competent, the board shall cause the chairperson and secretary to execute and deliver to the applicant a license authorizing him to do plumbing in the city. 
(i)  All original licenses may be renewed and all renewal licenses may be renewed by the plumbing board at the dates of their expiration. Such renewal licenses shall be granted, without a reexamination, upon the written application of the licensee filed with the board and showing that his purposes and condition remain unchanged, unless it is made to appear by affidavit before the board that the applicant is no longer competent, or entitled to such renewal license, in which event the renewal license shall not be granted until the applicant has undergone the required examination. 
(j)  All original and renewal licenses shall be good for one year or two years from the date of issuance as determined by the plumbing board, except that any license may be revoked or suspended by the plumbing board at any time upon a hearing upon sufficient written, sworn charges filed with the board showing the holder of the license to be incompetent or guilty of a willful breach of the rules, regulations, or requirements of the board or of the laws or municipal ordinances relating thereto or of other causes sufficient for the revocation or suspension of his license, of which charges and hearing the holder of such license shall have written notice. 
(k)  The licensing requirements of subsections (i) and (j) of this section shall not apply to employees of the water utility acting within the scope of their employment. 
(l)  The board shall be responsible for making such reports and performing such additional duties as the governing body may, from time to time, designate. All actions of the board shall be subject to the review and supervision of the governing body. 
(Code 1975, § 2-210; Ord. No. 95-32, § 1, 5-2-95; Ord. No. 98-36, § 1, 9-14-98) 
Cross reference- Bond schedule, app. A. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 18-1901 through 18-1909. 
Secs. 18-142-18-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - ELECTRICAL LICENSING BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; electrical code, § 18-256 et seq. 
State Law reference- Electrical inspections, R.R.S. 1943, § 81-2130. 

Sec. 18-161. - Appointment; membership; organization; duties; license. 
(a)  The governing body shall appoint an electrical licensing board, to consist of three members: 
(1)  The electrical superintendent; 
(2)  The electrical inspector; and 
(3)  One other member who shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the council. 
All members shall be residents of the city. 
(b)  At the time of the board's first meeting in August of each year, the board shall organize by selecting from the membership one person to serve as chairman. The electrical inspector shall serve as secretary. It shall be the duty of the secretary to keep the full and correct minutes and records of all meetings and to file them with the city clerk, where they shall be available for public inspection at any reasonable time. The board shall be funded by the governing body out of the combined utilities fund. The board shall meet at such times as the governing body may designate. Special meetings may be held upon the call of the chairman, or any two members of the board. A majority of the membership shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of doing business. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the board to adopt rules and regulations, not inconsistent with other city ordinances and state law, for the construction, alteration and inspection of electrical connections and wires placed in or in connection with every building in the city. 
(d)  All members may, after a public hearing before the council, for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office or other good and sufficient cause be removed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the council. 
(e)  Any member of the board shall have the authority to order water, sewer, electric or gas service lines or pipes shut off and service disconnected during any period when the use of such lines, pipes or apparatus appears hazardous to the public health, safety or welfare. The board shall have the authority to compel the owner or contractor of any building to first submit the plans for any electrical work that is to be installed for approval prior to such installation. 
(f)  Any person desiring to do any electrical work or to work at the business of an electrician in the city shall make a written application to the board for an examination to test the applicant's practical and theoretical knowledge of electrical wiring, fire prevention and appliance installation unless such person shall hold a valid state license, in which case he shall be allowed to practice his trade or skill without further licensing of any kind if electrical permits are taken out and inspections are made in accordance with requirements of the city. Upon successful completion of the test, the board may then cause the chairman and secretary to execute and deliver to the applicant a license authorizing him to do electrical work in the city. Licenses so granted will be automatically renewable by the board; provided, the board shall have the discretion to waive the examination if the board is satisfied by other evidence that the applicant is competent to do electrical work. If it comes to the attention of the board that the licensee may not be competent or entitled to renewal, the board shall have the power to compel the licensee to take an examination prior to renewal. Any license so granted may be removed at any time by the board for good and sufficient cause after a hearing before the board. 
(g)  The board shall be responsible for making such reports and performing such additional duties as the governing body may designate. All actions of the board shall be subject to the review and supervision of the governing body. 
(h)  No member of the governing body shall serve as a member of the board, and no member of the board shall serve in the capacity of both the chairman and secretary of the board. 
(Code 1975, § 2-211) 
Secs. 18-162-18-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - BUILDING PERMITS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Building code, § 18-216 et seq. 

Sec. 18-181. - Required. 
(a)  Any person intending to construct, improve or repair a building or other structure within the city or within the zoning jurisdiction of the city shall, before proceeding with such work, or commencing any excavation in connection therewith, file in the office of the city clerk a written application designating: 
(1)  The kind of building, structure or addition, or character or extent of repairs he intends to erect or make and materials of which they are composed; 
(2)  The legal description and location of the real estate; 
(3)  The part or portion of the real estate to be occupied by the building and the approximate cost; 
(4)  The public utilities, city or otherwise, proposed to be connected with and available for the use of the occupants; and 
(5)  A detailed description of the type of construction and materials used. 
Applications shall be filed with the code official, who shall investigate the proposed construction; and if he finds that the work will conform to the laws of the state, the provisions of this Code, and other ordinances and regulations of the city, the code official shall approve such application. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  If an application for a building permit shall be disapproved by the code official, or if any citizen of the city shall file objections in writing to the issuance of such permit before such permit is issued, the code official shall present such application, together with all plans and specifications and findings, to the governing body at their next regular meeting; and the governing body then shall determine whether the permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1975, § 3-801) 
Sec. 18-182. - Fees. 
    The code official shall require each applicant to deposit with the city clerk written proof that the applicant has paid to the city collector the requisite building permit fee set by resolution of the governing body and on file in the office of the city clerk for each type of construction or repair proposed. If construction on any structure is commenced prior to securing a building permit, the fees for the permit and inspection of such structure shall be double those set forth in the schedule of fees on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 3-802) 
Sec. 18-183. - Display of permit card. 
    The contractor or other person engaged in the erection or repair of any structure shall keep posted in a conspicuous place at all times until final approval by the code official a card showing that a building permit has been granted and the number of the permit. 
(Code 1975, § 3-803) 
Sec. 18-184. - Stopping work. 
    It shall be unlawful for any contractor or other person engaged in the actual work of erecting any building or other structure or of making any improvements or repairs on any such building or structure to proceed with the work until he knows the owner has obtained a permit as provided by this division. The code official may order cessation of any work so started before the issuance of such permit. 
(Code 1975, § 3-805) 
Sec. 18-185. - Revocation of permit. 
    Any building permit issued pursuant to this division shall be automatically revoked six months after the date of issuance if the proposed construction, improvement or repair for which such permit was issued has not been commenced. Improvement or repair of an already existing structure shall be deemed to have commenced when actual alterations of the building have taken place and not otherwise. After a permit has been revoked under this section, the applicant may reapply for a new permit. 
(Code 1975, § 3-806) 
Sec. 18-186. - Failure to construct. 
    It shall be unlawful for a permittee to fail to complete the construction, improvement or repairs of any building within one year from the date of the issuance of his permit. A certificate of satisfactory construction shall be prima facie evidence of the completion of such construction, improvement or repairs. Each day that construction is not completed or the building is not returned to the condition in which it existed prior to the issuance of the permit shall constitute a separate offense. A permittee may apply to the governing body for an extension of time by written application filed with the code official at least 30 days prior to the expiration of the permit. The code official may render a decision or forward such request to the governing body who shall act on the application at its next meeting and may approve the extension upon a showing by the permittee of a reasonable cause why the construction, improvements or repairs have not been completed and further upon showing that a reasonable effort is being made to complete the construction. 
(Code 1975, § 3-807) 
Secs. 18-187-18-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Code official, § 18-51 et seq.; building permits, § 18-181 et seq. 

Sec. 18-216. - Adopted by reference. 
    To provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe and stable design, methods of construction and uses of materials in buildings erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, relocated and converted, the International Building Code, 2012 edition, and all subsequent editions and amendments thereto when adopted and approved by the State of Nebraska or an agency thereof, is incorporated by reference in addition to all amendments as though printed in full in this section insofar as the code does not conflict with the statutes of the state. One copy of the building code is on file at the office of the city clerk and is available for public inspection at any reasonable time. The provisions of the building code shall be controlling throughout the city and throughout its zoning jurisdiction. 
(Code 1975, § 9-101; Ord. No. 93-13, § 1, 4-6-93; Ord. No. 96-30, § 1, 11-12-96; Ord. No. 2008-9, § 1, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 2018-5, § 1, 4-9-18) 
Sec. 18-217. - Enforcement by code official. 
    It shall be the duty of code official to enforce the provisions of the building code and adopted by reference in this article as well as the International Residential Code for One and Two Family Dwellings, 2012 edition, and all subsequent editions in addition to all amendments as though printed in full in this section insofar as the code does not conflict with statutes of the state. The provisions of the residential code shall be controlling throughout the city and throughout its zoning jurisdiction. 
(Code 1975, § 9-102; Ord. No. 2008-9, § 2, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 2018-5, § 2, 4-9-18) 
Sec. 18-218. - Permit inspections. 
    Upon application for a building permit, the code official shall make an investigation of the proposed work. It shall be his duty to report on whether the proposed work conforms to state statute, the provisions of the building code, and all other ordinances of the city. If no good cause of any nature exists why such work should not be done, the code official shall approve the application. 
(Code 1975, § 9-103) 
Sec. 18-219. - Building permits; duplicate to county assessor. 
    Whenever a building permit is issued for the erection, alteration, or repair of any building within the city's jurisdiction and the improvement is $2,500.00 or more, a duplicate of such permit shall be issued to the county assessor. 
(Code 1975, § 9-103.01; Ord. No. 2004-11, § 1, 2-9-04) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1743. 
Sec. 18-220. - Certificate of satisfactory construction. 
    Upon completion of a building in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the code official shall deliver to the holder of the building permit for the building a certificate of satisfactory construction. No utilities shall be made available for use in such building until such certificate is issued and delivered. 
(Code 1975, § 9-104) 
Sec. 18-221. - Commencing work without a permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any contractor or other person engaged in erecting any building or structure or making improvements or repairs to any building or structure to proceed with the work until the owner displays to him the building permit required by section 18-181 of this Code. The code official may order cessation of any work begun before the issuance of such a permit. 
(Code 1975, § 9-105) 
Sec. 18-222. - Additional standards. 
    In addition to the standards of the International Building Code, 2012 Edition and all subsequent editions and amendments thereto, the following shall apply to temporary structures: 
(1)  Purpose. This section provides regulations authorizing temporary uses and structures. These provisions are intended to permit occasional uses and activities of short duration, when consistent with the objectives of the building code and when compatible with the surrounding uses. They are further intended to prevent temporary uses from taking on the operating character of permanent uses. 
(2)  Temporary uses. Outdoor special sales including parking lot sales, tent sales, flea markets or similar activities may be allowed for 12 days. A maximum of three events shall be allowed on a site during one calendar year. All such sales must be located in the area described in this section. 
(3)  Temporary structures. Pre-manufactured free-standing structures typically constructed of light-weight pre-formed metal or plastic tube frames with sheet metal panels or fabrics to cover and protect the contents and tents may be allowed with the restrictions contained herein in an area one block east and one block west of Dakota Avenue from the Missouri River south to 39 th Street and from East 10 th Street north to the Missouri River and for two blocks west of Dakota Avenue from West 19 th Street to the Missouri River. 
(4)  Time period. All temporary structures or tents shall be allowed within the permitted area for a maximum of 12 days including erection of the structure or tent and removal of the same. 
(5)  Location. The temporary structure or tent can only be located on property owned by the applicant and adjacent or near a permanent business structure. 
(6)  Size. The temporary structures and tents regulated by this section are 100 square feet or larger. 
(7)  Approval. The installation of a temporary structure or tent within the limited area must be reviewed by the design commission established by article IV, chapter 78 of the South Sioux City Municipal Code and recommended to the city council for approval. The city council shall make the final decision as to the approval or denial of a permit for a temporary structure or a tent. 
(8)  Permit application. An application to conduct a temporary use in a temporary structure or tent shall be filed with the city clerk not less than 14 days before the event and shall include (1) a site plan showing existing parking and buildings and location of the proposed use; (2) a statement describing the nature of the proposed temporary use and structure; (3) the hours of and duration of the temporary use or structure; and (4) other information as determined by the City Clerk and Planning Director necessary to evaluate the proposed use. 
(9)  Issuance of permit. The city council will approve the temporary permit only after making the following determinations: (1) the use will comply with all regulations contained herein; (2) time and frequency of operation are acceptable; and (3) the arrangement for parking and circulation allow safe access to the site. The hours of operation and duration of the temporary use permit shall be explicitly stated on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2009-11, § 1, 9-28-09; Ord. No. 2012-11, § 1, 8-27-12; Ord. No. 2018-5, § 6, 4-9-18) 
Secs. 18-223-18-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Electrical inspector, § 18-71 et seq.; electrical licensing board, § 18-161 et seq.; electrical requirements for swimming pool, § 18-621; natural gas and electric systems for mobile homes, § 62-48; electrical signs, § 86-27; utilities, ch. 114; electric system, § 114-136 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-256. - Adopted by reference. 
    To provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe and fireproof installation, methods of connection, and uses of materials in the installation of electrical wiring and appliances, the National Electric Code, 2017 edition, as recommended and published by the National Fire Protection Association, printed in book or pamphlet form, in addition to all mended editions, is incorporated by reference as though printed in full in this section insofar as the code does not conflict with the statutes of the state. Three copies of the electrical code are on file at the office of the city clerk and are available for public inspection at any reasonable time. The provisions of the electrical code shall be controlling throughout the city and throughout its zoning jurisdiction. 
(Code 1975, § 9-401; Ord. No. 2009-4, § 1, 3-9-09; Ord. No. 2014-2, § 1, 4-28-14; Ord. No. 2018-5, § 7, 4-9-18) 
Sec. 18-257. - Enforcement by electrical inspector. 
    It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 9-402) 
Sec. 18-258. - Additional standards. 
    In addition to the standards of the International Property Maintenance Code 2012 edition and the 2017 National Electric Code, the following shall apply: 
    All interior house wiring shall be grounded from the main panel box to the cold water pipe on the street side of the water meter, or to the nearest cold water pipe if the water meter is properly bonded with approved iron clamps; provided, that if the premises have no connection with the municipal water mains, a driven ground shall be installed. Driven grounds shall also be installed in such other cases as the electrical inspector shall direct. All interior wiring installed in the zoning limits of the city in buildings used or employed for business or commercial purposes shall be placed in conduit of proper size; provided, that all interior wiring installed for business or commercial purposes in the zoning limits in buildings where gasoline, grain, explosives or any other combustible products or materials are sold, manufactured or stored shall be placed in rigid or thin-wall conduit or by any other methods approved by the electrical inspector. In all buildings in the zoning limits used or employed for residential purposes, proper size nonmetallic sheath cable wiring may be used. In multiple dwellings or apartment houses occupied or to be occupied by 13 or more families, and in hospitals, all interior wiring shall be installed in proper size thin-wall or ridged pipe conduit. Also no wiring in any building or premises in the zoning limits shall be placed in or covered with concrete without first being placed in a conduit. 
(Code 1975, § 9-403; Ord. No. 2018-5, § 8, 4-9-18) 
Sec. 18-259. - Unlawful wiring. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install or allow to remain installed within the city any interior building or house wiring, or to any connections, whether inside or outside, unless the same are in strict conformity with the provisions of this article, other ordinances of the city, and the statutes of the state. 
(Code 1975, § 9-404) 
Secs. 18-260-18-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICIANS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 18-281. - License required. 
    No person shall install any electric apparatus within the corporate limits without first having obtained a license to do so from the state electrical board. All licensees under the state electrical act, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 81-2101-81-2145, shall be required to obtain an occupation tax certificate issued by the electrical inspector. Application for an occupation tax certificate shall be made to the electrical inspector in writing showing the name and residence of the applicant, the business location of the applicant and such other information as may be required. 
(Code 1975, § 10-412; Ord. No. 94-5, § 1, 3-8-94) 
Sec. 18-282. - Licenses available; scope of licenses. 
    Electrician's licenses available and the scope of the work authorized by those licenses shall be determined by the state electrical board. 
(Code 1975, § 10-413; Ord. No. 94-5, § 2, 3-8-94) 
Sec. 18-283. - Bond required. 
    Before any electrician's license shall be issued by the electrical licensing board, the applicant shall execute and file with the city clerk a bond in a sum of $10,000.00, conditioned that the licensee shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from all liability caused by any negligent or intentional act arising from his electrical work or violation of this Code and shall pay all fines imposed upon him for any violation. The obligee of the bond shall be the city, and action may be maintained on the board by anyone injured by a breach of its conditions for a period of one year after the completion of any electrical work. Also, before a license is issued by the electrical licensing board, the applicant shall file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance that the applicant has general liability insurance with a minimum limit of $300,000.00 per occurrence; and the certificate of insurance shall remain valid and in force during the term of the license. 
(Code 1975, § 10-416; Ord. No. 94-5, § 5, 3-8-94) 
Cross reference- Bond schedule, app. A. 
Sec. 18-284. - Expiration and renewal of certificates. 
    Occupation tax certificates shall expire on April 30 of the year in which they are issued, and shall not be assignable. Occupation tax certificates, at the time of their expiration, may be renewed upon recommendation of the electrical licensing board, certification of the proper license issued by the state electrical board, and payment of the required occupation tax. 
(Code 1975, § 10-418; Ord. No. 94-5, § 7, 3-8-94) 
Sec. 18-285. - Unlawful use of name. 
    No licensed electrician shall allow his name to be used by another person, directly or indirectly, to obtain a permit for the installation of any work; and if any licensed electrician violates this provision, the electrical licensing board shall forthwith file a complaint with the state electrical board. In addition to having his license revoked, such electrician may be prosecuted under section 1-9. 
(Code 1975, § 10-420; Ord. No. 94-5, § 9, 3-8-94) 
Sec. 18-286. - Fees. 
    The city collector shall collect all licensing and renewal fees as occupation taxes and shall credit the same to the proper fund designated by the governing body. The governing body shall have the right to classify electricians for the purpose of setting license and renewal fees in such categories as they may in their discretion set. Such categories are declared to be reasonable and nondiscriminatory. The actual amounts of the license and renewal fees shall be on file at the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 10-421) 
Secs. 18-287-18-320. - Reserved.

Sec. 18-323. - Discontinuance of service. 
    Any distributor of gas shall discontinue gas service to any premises where any gas-fired space-heating equipment is installed, connected or used contrary to the provisions of this article. Upon the determination of any such distributor that new space-heating equipment has been installed, connected or used contrary to the provisions of this article, such distributor shall forthwith notify in writing the owners or occupants of the premises that all gas service to such premises for space-heating purposes will be disconnected 20 days after service of such notice. The distributor shall discontinue gas service at the end of the period unless such equipment has been disconnected and removed. 
(Code 1975, § 9-504) 
Sec. 18-324. - Unlawful connection of space heaters. 
    No person shall connect or install gas-burning space-heating equipment where the use of such equipment, or the installation or connection of the equipment, is contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 9-505)

ARTICLE VI. - HOUSING CODES[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) ---

Sec. 18-356. - Adopted by reference. 
    To provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe and stable design, methods of construction, and uses of materials in houses erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, relocated and converted, the International Residential Code for One and Two Family Dwellings, 2012 edition, and all subsequent editions in addition to all amendments as though printed in full in this section insofar as the code does not conflict with the statutes of the state, is incorporated by reference. One copy of the housing code is on file at the office of the city clerk and is available for public inspection at any reasonable time. The provisions of the housing code shall be controlling throughout the city and throughout its zoning jurisdiction. 
(Code 1975, § 9-201; Ord. No. 93-13, § 2, 4-6-93; Ord. No. 2008-9, § 4, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 2018-5, § 10, 4-9-18) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt building regulations, R.R.S. 1943, § 19-922. 
Sec. 18-357. - Housing authority; continued existence as housing agency. 
(a)  The local housing authority established under prior state law and in existence on January 1, 2000, shall have continued existence as a housing agency under the Nebraska Housing Agency Act. 
(b)  The local housing agency shall conduct its operations consistent with the Nebraska Housing Agency Act. All property, rights in land, buildings, records, and equipment and any funds, money, revenue, receipts, or assets of the authority belong to the agency as successor. All obligations, debts, commitments, and liabilities of the authority are obligations, debts, commitments, and liabilities of the successor agency. 
(c)  Any resolution by the authority and any action taken by the authority prior to January 1, 2000, with regard to any project or program which is to completed within or to be conducted for a 12-month period following January 1, 2000, and which resolution or action is lawful under state law as it existed prior to January 1, 2000, is a lawful resolution or action of the successor agency and binding upon the successor agency and enforceable by or against the agency notwithstanding that such resolution or action is inconsistent with, not authorized by, or prohibited under the provisions of the Nebraska Housing Agency Act. 
(d)  All commissioners of the local housing agency and all officers, legal counsel, technical experts, directors, and other appointees or employees of the agency holding office or employment by virtue of any such prior law on January 1, 2000, shall be deemed to have been appointed or employed under the Nebraska Housing Agency Act. 
(Ord. No. 2000-33, § 1, 10-9-00) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions Neb. R.R.S. 1943, § 71-1576. 
Secs. 18-358-18-390. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MECHANICAL CODE[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbers and heating and cooling contractors, § 18-461 et seq.; utilities, ch. 114. 

Sec. 18-391. - Adopted by reference. 
    To provide certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe and stable design, methods of construction and the control of buildings and structures erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, relocated and converted, the International Mechanical Code, 2012 edition, and all subsequent editions in addition to all amendments as though printed in full in this section insofar as the code does not conflict with the statutes of the state, is incorporated by reference. One copy of the mechanical code is on file in the office of the city clerk and available for public inspection at any reasonable time. The provisions of the mechanical code shall be controlling throughout the city and throughout its zoning jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 93-13, § 4, 4-6-93; Ord. No. 96-30, § 3, 11-12-96; Ord. No. 2008-9, § 5, 4-14-08; Ord. No. 2018-5, § 11, 4-9-18) 
Sec. 18-392. - Plastic pipe. 
    No plastic pipe shall be allowed to be placed in any building within the zoning jurisdiction of the city; however, plastic pipe is allowed for use as waste and vent piping above ground and schedule 40 PVC (polyvinyl chloride) is allowed for use below grade. All water service lines shall conform with current American Water Works Association standards. The use of alternative materials may be approved by the code official. 
(Code 1975, § 9-302) 
Sec. 18-393. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fixtures means bathtubs, water closets, lavatories, kitchen sinks, wash tray sinks, urinals, slop sinks, and floor drains. 
(Code 1975, § 9-303) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-394. - Enforcement by plumbing inspector. 
    It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector to enforce the provisions of the plumbing code as adopted by reference in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 9-304) 
Sec. 18-395. - Inspections. 
    The plumbing inspector shall inspect all work performed and materials used in the construction, repair and installation of all units, systems, equipment or device of any sort through which water flows or in which water is used, or through which fuel oil, kerosene, natural or artificial gas flows or in which such fuel is used. Such inspections shall take place as often as the plumbing inspector deems necessary but in all cases shall occur at the following times: 
(1)  When the lines conveying such substances have been installed and before such lines or pipes have been covered from view. 
(2)  When such appliances, equipment and devices using such substances have been put in place. 
(3)  After the completion of the work of construction, repair or installation but before any object subject to inspection is placed in use. 
(Code 1975, § 9-305) 
Sec. 18-396. - Certificate of approval. 
    Upon completion of any plumbing work, the plumber doing such work shall notify the office of the city clerk. Within 24 hours of such notification, the plumbing inspector shall make the final inspection of all plumbing work thus completed. If all the provisions of this article have been complied with, the inspector shall issue a certificate of approval. Such certificate shall acknowledge that all plumbing work so inspected has been installed in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1975, § 9-306) 
Sec. 18-397. - Use. 
    No plumbing shall be used until inspected by the plumbing inspector or his assistant, and a certificate of approval or a certificate of completion has been issued. 
(Code 1975, § 9-307) 
Sec. 18-398. - Prohibition of lead pipes, solder and flux. 
    Any pipe, solders or flux used in the installation or repair of any residential or nonresidential facility connected to the public water supply system shall be lead free, which means: 
(1)  Solders and flux, not more than two percent lead; and 
(2)  Pipe and pipe fittings, not more than eight percent lead. 
(Code 1975, § 9-308) 
State Law reference- Safe Drinking Water Act, R.R.S. 1943, § 71-5301 et seq. 
Secs. 18-399-18-430. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IX. - PLUMBERS AND HEATING AND COOLING CONTRACTORS[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference- Board of plumbing examiners, § 18-141 et seq.; gas code, § 18-321 et seq.; mechanical code, § 18-391 et seq.; plumbing code, § 18-431 et seq. 

Sec. 18-461. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall engage in or work at the business of plumbing in the city until he shall have registered for one of the available types of licenses available from the city. Such application shall be made in writing, indicating the name of the applicant, the business location of the applicant, and such other information as may be required. 
(b)  The plumbing inspector shall recommend and the board of plumbing examiners shall issue licenses to those persons who have been issued a valid and unexpired plumber's license by the state; provided, such persons shall have complied with the other terms and conditions (except the examination) precedent to the issuance of licenses as required in this article. If the applicant holds a license issued by the state, the license required in this article shall be in the form of an occupation tax certificate. 
(Code 1975, § 10-401) 
State Law reference- License required, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1910. 
Sec. 18-462. - Licenses available. 
    The following licenses shall be available from the city: 
(1)  Contractor's license. Any firm that does construction work requiring one of the licenses described in this section shall be licensed in one of the categories of licensee in the name of such firm provided that such firm shall have a licensee who is duly licensed as provided in this article. Such licensee must be a bona fide officer of the firm or an employee who is regularly employed by the firm and is actually engaged in the planning, superintending and practical installation of the licensed work. The licensee listed and licensed by such firm shall be in actual charge of and responsible for the work done by such firm. This individual must qualify as a master licensee to enable the firm to hold a master licensee's license; and if the individual withdraws from or ceases to be connected with the firm, the licensing board shall forthwith revoke the license of the firm. 
(2)  Master plumber and gas fitter. A master plumber and gas fitter's license shall be issued only to persons having at least five years' actual experience as a journeyman plumber and gas fitter or the equivalent, and who shall pass an examination as to qualifications, which shall be given by the plumber licensing board. 
(3)  Journeyman plumber and gas fitter. A journeyman plumber and gas fitter's license shall be issued only to persons having at least four years' actual experience as an apprentice plumber or the equivalent, and who shall pass an examination as to qualifications given by the plumber licensing board. 
(4)  Master drainlayer. A master drainlayer's license shall be issued only to persons having at least five years' actual experience in drainlaying or plumbing and who shall pass an examination as to qualifications given by the plumber licensing board. 
(5)  Master heating/cooling. A master heating/cooling license shall be issued only to persons having at least five years' actual experience in the installation and repair of units and appliances used for building heating and in sheet metal work and including all types of building heating or the equivalent, and who shall pass an examination as to qualifications given by the plumber licensing board. 
(6)  Water treatment. A water treatment license shall be issued only to persons having one year's experience in the installation of water softeners or water treatment units. 
(7)  Apprentice plumber. An apprentice plumber's license shall be issued only to persons enrolled in a registered apprenticeship training program accredited by the U.S. Department of Labor or the equivalent as determined by the plumber licensing board, and employed by the holder of a master plumber license. 
(8)  Inactive. A license holder who is not actively engaged in the business for which he or she is licensed may have their license placed on inactive status. The fee for an inactive license shall be $10.00 annually and the bond and insurance requirements are waived. 
(Code 1975, § 10-402; Ord. No. 95-31, § 1, 5-2-95; Ord. No. 2003-38, § 1, 8-11-03) 
Sec. 18-463. - Scope of licenses. 
(a)  A master plumber and gas fitter's license shall entitle the holder to place, replace, repair, install and construct pipes, fittings, appliances, accessories, fixtures, materials and systems for the conveyance, use and treatment of water, wastes and fluids, and installation, cleaning, repairing or sale of natural gas piping systems and appliances, and to carry on a general plumbing and gas business. 
(b)  A journeyman plumber and gas fitter's license shall entitle the holder to do all things a master plumber and gas fitter may do, but only while under the direct supervision of a person licensed as a master plumber and gas fitter. 
(c)  A master drainlayer's license shall entitle the holder to install, construct, lay, replace or repair sanitary sewer tile lines, including mains, and septic tank systems and fields outside of buildings. A master plumber and gas fitter's license shall entitle the holder to all privileges of a drainlayer's license. 
(d)  A master heating/cooling license shall entitle the holder to carry on a general business in the installation, repair, manufacture, replacement and fitting of any system, unit, equipment, accessory, appliance or device for the production of heat for household, commercial or industrial use, and installation, cleaning, repairing or sale of natural gas piping systems and appliances. 
(e)  A water treatment license shall entitle the holder to install, repair or replace units, appliances and devices for the softening of water for household or commercial use, but shall not entitle the holder to make any connections with any water or sanitary sewer system. 
(f)  An apprentice plumber's license shall entitle the holder to work under the supervision of a master or journeyman plumber. 
(Code 1975, § 10-403; Ord. No. 95-31, § 2, 5-2-95) 
Sec. 18-464. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005-31, § 1, adopted Sept. 26, 2005, repealed § 18-464 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to temporary licenses as enacted by Code 1975, § 10-404; as amended by Ord. No. 95-31, § 3, adopted May 2, 1995. 
Sec. 18-465. - Examination. 
    Before an applicant shall be registered in one of the categories prescribed in section 18-463, he shall submit to an examination to determine his fitness and competency to engage in the business of the type of license applied for, which examination shall be given by the board of plumbing examiners or an equivalent examination approved by the board of plumbing examiners. Upon the payment of the required registration fee, such applicant after having by such examination shown himself to the satisfaction of the licensing board to be fit, competent and qualified to engage in the business of the type of license applied for and having gained final approval from the board, shall be registered and given a license signed by the code official. 
    Any applicant who has not held an active license for a period of two or more years prior to making application therefore, shall take the examination required by this section. 
(Code 1975, § 10-405; Ord. No. 95-31, § 4, 5-2-95; Ord. No. 2003-38, § 2, 8-11-03) 
State Law reference- Examination, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1907. 
Sec. 18-466. - Bond; insurance. 
    Before a contractor's license is issued by the board of plumbing examiners, the applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond in the penal sum of $10,000.00 signed by one or more sufficient sureties to be approved by the governing body or a surety bond of the same amount issued by an approved corporate surety company. This bond shall contain the condition that the applicant shall defend, save, keep harmless, and indemnify the city from all liabilities, claims, damages, judgments, costs and expenses of every nature and description caused by the willful or negligent conduct of the licensee while engaged in the business of plumbing. The obligee of the bond shall be the city, and action may be maintained on the board by anyone injured by a breach of the conditions of the bond or of the covenants contained in the required endorsement on the policy of insurance for a period of one year after the completion of any work. Also, before a license is issued by the licensing board, the applicant shall file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance that the applicant has general liability insurance with a minimum limit of $300,000.00 per occurrence; and this certificate of insurance shall remain valid and in force during the term of the license. 
(Code 1975, § 10-406; Ord. No. 95-31, § 5, 5-2-95) 
Sec. 18-467. - Expiration and renewal of license. 
    All licenses issued under this article shall expire on December 31 of the year in which they are issued and shall not be assignable. Licenses, at the time of their expiration, may be renewed upon recommendation of the board of plumbing examiners, without an examination and upon payment of the required renewal fee. No license shall be renewed unless the city clerk shall first receive authorization from the licensing board. Any license that has not been renewed prior to the expiration date shall expire 30 days thereafter and may not be renewed without recommendation of the licensing board, which may require a written examination. If the licensing board recommends renewal without examination after expiration, the annual fee shall be twice the amount established by the governing body. 
(Code 1975, § 10-408; Ord. No. 95-31, § 7, 5-2-95) 
Sec. 18-468. - Revocation of license. 
    The board of plumbing examiners by a majority vote shall have power to revoke any license if the license was obtained through error or fraud, or if the recipient is shown to be grossly incompetent or has a second time willfully violated any of the provisions of the plumbing code. If a license is revoked, the holder of the license shall not apply for licensing for one year after such revocation. 
(Code 1975, § 10-409; Ord. No. 95-31, § 8, 5-2-95) 
State Law reference- Revocation, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1909. 
Sec. 18-469. - Unlawful transfer of license. 
    No licensee under this article shall allow his name to be used by another person, directly or indirectly, to obtain a permit for the installation of any work; and if any licensee violates this provision, the board of plumbing examiners shall forthwith revoke the license issued to such licensee. In addition to having his license revoked, such licensee may be prosecuted under section 1-9. 
(Code 1975, § 10-410; Ord. No. 95-31, § 9, 5-2-95) 
Sec. 18-470. - License fees. 
    The city collector shall collect all license and renewal fees as occupation taxes and shall credit them to such funds of the city as the governing body may designate. The governing body shall have the right to classify plumbers for the purpose of setting license and renewal fees in such categories as they may in their discretion set. Such categories are declared to be reasonable and nondiscriminatory. The actual amounts of the license and renewal fees shall be on file at the office of the city clerk. The initial fees for a license shall be twice the amount of all applicable license and fees for renewal of a license. The fees for a contractor's license shall be twice the amount of all applicable license and renewal fees and occupation taxes if the annual fees, bond and certificate of insurance is not submitted to the city clerk on or before January 20th of each license year. 
(Code 1975, § 10-411; Ord. No. 2003-38, § 3, 8-11-03) 
State Law reference- Fees, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1911. 
Secs. 18-471-18-500. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - FENCES[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference- Fence for swimming pools, § 18-620. 

Sec. 18-501. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fence means any structure or partition erected for the purposes of enclosing a piece of land or dividing a piece of land into distinct portions or separating two contiguous pieces of land; however, it shall not include ornamental fences less than two feet in height. 
(Code 1975, § 9-601) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-502. - Conformity to article; permit required. 
(a)  No fence shall be erected, constructed, enlarged, altered or relocated within the zoning jurisdiction of the city unless it conforms with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Any person desiring to erect, construct, enlarge, alter or relocate a fence within the zoning jurisdiction of the city shall make application for a building permit to the code official. It shall be the responsibility of the contractor or owner of the real estate where the fence is to be erected to obtain the building permit prior to commencement of construction. 
(Code 1975, § 9-602; Ord. No. 93-1, § 1, 2-2-93) 
Sec. 18-503. - Requirements and standards. 
    The following requirements shall be applied to all fences constructed within the zoning jurisdiction of the city: 
(1)  Fences shall not be constructed within two feet of any public sidewalk or within one foot of any alley or right-of-way. 
(2)  Fences shall not exceed 48 inches in height within the front yard setback requirements of the zoning ordinances of the city. 
(3)  Fences shall not exceed six feet in height in any rear yard; however, special permission may be obtained from the city council to exceed six feet in height upon satisfactory proof to him that a fence exceeding six feet is necessary for security reasons. 
(4)  Fences that will obstruct the view of approaching operators of motor vehicles shall not be constructed on corner lots. 
(5)  All materials used in the construction of a fence within the city must be approved by the code official or the city council. 
(Code 1975, § 9-603; Ord. No. 93-1, § 2, 2-2-93) 
Sec. 18-504. - Types restricted. 
    Fences shall not be erected or maintained within the zoning limits that are constructed of barbed wire or charged with electricity. Upon application to and a permit received from the governing body, barbed wire fences or electrically charged fences may be erected or allowed to remain if such fences are built at least three feet inside the lot line, so as not to endanger the public use of any street, sidewalk or right-of-way. Fences constructed of barbed wire or charged by electricity may be used for agricultural purposes only outside of the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1975, § 9-604; Ord. No. 93-1, § 3, 2-2-93) 
Sec. 18-505. - Easements. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any lot or parcel of land on which a public utility easement exists to erect, maintain or suffer to remain on such easement any fence that does not comply with the following requirements and standards: 
(1)  All fences erected on a public utility easement must be constructed with a gate having a minimum width of ten feet across the public utility easement. 
(2)  All immediately adjoining properties where a fence is located across a public utility easement shall also have a gate of a minimum width of ten feet for access to the easement. 
(3)  Prior to issuance of a permit for construction of any fence on a public utility easement, permission must be obtained from the city utility department and the code official. 
(4)  The owner of the lot or parcel of land where the fence is to be constructed across a public utility easement must execute a written agreement allowing the city access to the public utility easement at all times. 
(5)  The gate across the public utility easement shall not be locked or secured in any manner that prohibits access by the city to the easement area. 
(b)  Each application for a permit to construct a fence across a public utility easement shall be reviewed on an individual basis to determine whether or not the proposal allows full and free access by the city to the public utility easement. If full and free access is not provided, the application shall not be approved. Any fence constructed in whole or in part on any public utility easement within the zoning jurisdiction of the city without express permission by the city and in full compliance with the provisions of this section is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1975, § 9-605; Ord. No. 93-1, § 4, 2-2-93; Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 7-5-95) 
Sec. 18-506. - Restricted use of easements. 
    There shall not be any buildings erected on or within one foot of public utility easements nor any bushes, trees or other obstructing vegetation planted on any public utility easement. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 2(9-606), 7-5-95) 
Sec. 18-507. - Access to easements. 
    The city shall at all times have access to public utility easements; and any obstructions on public utility easements may be removed, dismantled or destroyed at the discretion of the city. The city shall not be responsible for any damage to fences constructed across any public utility easement that prohibit access by the city to the easement area. All obstructions on the public utility easement shall be at the risk of the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 3(9-607), 7-5-95) 
Sec. 18-508. - Exemptions to easement requirements. 
    Section 18-505, concerning construction of fences across public utility easements, does not apply to fences in existence prior to the passage of that section; except that on sale or transfer of the property or upon notice by the city where a nonconforming fence is located, such fence shall be made to conform with the requirements of this article or removed within 30 days of closing or transfer or within 30 days of notice to conform issued by the code official. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 4(9-608), 7-5-95) 
Secs. 18-509-18-540. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MOVING BUILDINGS[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 94. 

Sec. 18-541. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move any building or structure within the city without a written permit to do so when such buildings or structure are wider than 8' 6?, or longer than 65' 0?, or higher than 14' 6? or of any other size which requires displacement of any city property. 
(b)  Application may be made to the city clerk and shall include the present and future location of the building to be moved, the proposed route, the equipment to be used, and such other information as the governing body may require. The application shall be accompanied by a certificate issued by the county treasurer to the effect that all the provisions regulating the moving of buildings have been complied with on the part of the owner of the real estate upon which the building is presently located. The city clerk shall refer the application to the chief of police for approval of the proposed route over which the building is to be moved. Upon approval of the police chief, the city clerk shall then issue the permit. 
(c)  A good and sufficient corporate surety bond or cash in an amount set by motion of the governing body and conditioned upon moving the building without doing damage to any private or city property shall be filed with the city clerk prior to the granting of any permit. 
(d)  No building moving permit shall be issued to move any building unless it affirmatively appears that the premises to or upon which such building is sought to be moved and placed has or will have made available to it water, sewer and electric service. 
(e)  There shall be no license issued or general permit given to anyone to move buildings at will or generally within the city. 
(Code 1975, § 10-476) 
Cross reference- Fee schedule, app. A. 
Sec. 18-542. - Deposit. 
    At such time as a building moving has been completed, the code official shall inspect the premises and report to the city clerk as to the extent of damages, if any, resulting from the relocation and whether any city laws have been violated during the operation. Upon a satisfactory report from the code official, the city clerk shall return the corporate surety bond or cash deposited by the applicant. If the basement, foundation or portion is not properly filled, covered or in a clean and sanitary condition, the governing body may apply the money deposited for the purpose of defraying the expense of correcting the conditions. If the expense of correcting the hazardous condition is greater than the amount of the deposit set by resolution of the governing body, the governing body may recover such excess expense by civil suit or otherwise as prescribed by law. 
(Code 1975, § 10-477) 
Secs. 18-543-18-575. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - LIGHTING AND THERMAL EFFICIENCY STANDARDS 

Sec. 18-576. - Need. 
(a)  This article shall be known as the Minimum Lighting and Thermal Efficiency Standards for Buildings. 
(b)  The city finds that there is a present and continuing need to provide for the development and implementation of minimum lighting and thermal efficiency standards for buildings to ensure coordination with federal policy under the International Energy Conservation Code 2009 Edition for all buildings, to promote the conservation of our dwindling energy resources, and to provide for the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1975, § 9-801; Ord. No. 2009-3, § 1, 3-9-09; Ord. No. 2012-21, § 1, 10-23-12) 
Sec. 18-577. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Addition means any construction added to an existing building that will increase the floor area of that building by five percent or more. 
    Architect or engineer means any person registered pursuant to R.R.S. 1943, § 81-847. 
    Building means any structure that utilizes or will utilize a heating system, cooling system or domestic hot water system, including new buildings, renovated buildings and additions, but not including any structure that has a consumption of traditional energy sources for all purposes not exceeding the energy equivalent of one watt per square foot. 
    Floor area means the total area of a building, expressed in square feet, that is within the exterior face of the shell of the structure that is heated or cooled. 
    Prime contractor means the person who has a contract with the owner and is the one responsible for the overall construction of any building or the installation of any component that affects the energy efficiency of the building. The term shall also mean a property owner who performs the work of a prime contractor. 
    Renovation means alterations on an existing building that will cost more than 50 percent of the replacement cost of such building at the time work is commenced or was not previously heated or cooled, for which a heating or cooling system is now proposed; except the restoration of historical buildings shall not be included. 
    Residential building means a building three stories or less that is used primarily as one or more dwelling units. 
    Standard means the Model Energy Code, 1995 edition, of the Council of American Building Officials. 
    Traditional energy sources means electricity, petroleum based fuels, uranium, coal, and all nonrenewable forms of energy. 
(Code 1975, § 9-802) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-578. - Applicability of standard. 
    The standard shall apply to all new buildings, or renovations of or additions to any existing buildings, on which construction is initiated on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived. 
(Code 1975, § 9-803) 
Sec. 18-579. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The following shall be exempt from this article: 
(1)  Any building that has a peak design rate of energy usage for all purposes of less than one watt, or 3.4 Btus per hour, per square foot of floor area. 
(2)  Any building that is neither heated nor cooled. 
(3)  Any building or portion owned by the United States of America. 
(4)  Any mobile home as defined by R.R.S. 1943, § 71-4603. 
(5)  Any manufactured housing unit as defined by R.R.S. 1943, § 71-1557(1). 
(6)  Any building: 
a.  Listed on the National Register of Historic Places; 
b.  Determined to be eligible for the National Register of Historic Places by the state historic preservation officer; or 
c.  Designated as an individual landmark or heritage preservation site by a municipality or located within a designated landmark or heritage preservation district. 
(7)  Any building to be renovated that is located within an area that has been designated blighted by the city. 
(b)  All residential buildings shall be exempt from lighting efficiency standards. 
(Code 1975, § 9-804) 
Sec. 18-580. - Compliance; request for determination of compliance; appeal. 
(a)  For purposes of ensuring compliance with the standard, the code official may conduct such inspections and investigations as are necessary to make a determination of compliance and may issue an order containing and resulting from the findings of such inspections and investigations; and a building owner may request that the office undertake a determination pursuant to this section. Such request shall include a list of reasons why the building owner believes such a determination is necessary. 
(b)  A building owner aggrieved by the code official's determination, or refusal to make such determination, may appeal such determination or refusal to the governing body. 
(c)  The code official may charge an amount sufficient to recover the costs of providing such determinations. 
(d)  Buildings constructed after the adoption of the standard shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1975, § 9-805) 
Sec. 18-581. - Inspection; investigations. 
(a)  The code official or any person designated by him shall conduct inspections and investigations necessary to enforce the standard and may, at reasonable hours, enter into any building and upon any premises within its jurisdiction for the purpose of examination to determine compliance with this article. Inspection shall be conducted only after permission has been granted by the owner or occupant or after a warrant has been issued pursuant to R.R.S. 1943, §§ 29-830-29-835. 
(b)  During construction, the code official or persons designated by him shall make periodic inspection to assure compliance with this article. 
(Code 1975, § 9-806) 
Sec. 18-582. - Building plans, submission for approval. 
(a)  Prior to the construction of, renovation of, or addition to any building covered by this article, the prime contractor shall file sufficient plans and specifications with the code official to enable him to make a determination whether such building will comply with the standard. The code official shall within 30 days of the filing approve or disapprove the plans and specifications. If disapproved, the reasons shall be set forth in writing to the prime contractor. 
(b)  If the code official determines that such construction, renovation or addition will comply with the standard, he shall issue a written permit, which the prime contractor shall display in a conspicuous place on the premises where the construction work is to be done. No construction, renovation or addition shall commence until a permit is issued and displayed as required by this section. 
(Code 1975, § 9-807) 
Sec. 18-583. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- At the request of the city this section was removed. Formerly said section pertained to building permit fees and derived from Code 1975, § 9-808. 
Cross reference- Fee schedule, app. A. 
Sec. 18-584. - When architect or engineer is retained. 
    If an architect or engineer is retained to perform work under this article, the architect or engineer shall place his state registration seal on all construction drawings, which shall indicate that the design meets the standard. The prime contractor shall build or cause to be built in accordance with the construction documents prepared by the architect or engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 9-809) 
Sec. 18-585. - Violation; penalty; enforcement. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be subject to a maximum fine of $100.00. In addition, the city may by an action in the district court enforce the provisions of this article through equity and injunctive processes. 
(Code 1975, § 9-810) 
Secs. 18-586-18-615. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 18-616. - Installation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or enlarge a residential swimming pool not enclosed in a permanent building in the city and within its zoning jurisdiction except in accordance with the following regulations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 1, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 18-617. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Swimming pool means any depression in the ground, either temporary or permanent, or a container of water, either temporary or permanent, and either above or below the ground in which water more than 24 inches in depth is contained and which is used primarily for the purpose of bathing and swimming. Hot tubs which have a cover that is locked or secured in place are exempt. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 2, 10-4-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-618. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install, enlarge or alter any private swimming pool unless a building permit has first been obtained from the code official. Application shall be on forms provided by the code official and shall be accompanied by plans drawn to scale showing the following: 
(1)  Pool dimensions. 
(2)  Location and type of waste disposal system. 
(3)  Location of pool on lot, distance from lot lines, and distance from structure. 
(4)  Fencing or landscape plan, or a combination of both. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 3, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 18-619. - Construction requirements. 
(a)  No swimming pool shall be located, erected, constructed or maintained closer to any side or rear lot line than allowed by zoning ordinance for permitted accessory building uses, and in no case shall the water line of any pool be less than four feet from any lot line. 
(b)  No direct or indirect connection shall be made to the sanitary sewer or septic system. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 4, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 18-620. - Fence. 
(a)  Swimming pools within the scope of this section or not enclosed within a permanent building shall be completely enclosed by a fence of sufficient strength to prevent access to the pool and shall be not less than 48 inches in height, so constructed as not to have voids, holes or openings larger than four inches in one dimension. Gates or doors shall be equipped with a self-closing and self-latching device for keeping the gate or door securely closed at all times when not in actual use. 
(b)  Aboveground pools with self-provided fencing to prevent unguarded entry will be allowed without separate additional fencing, providing the self-provided fence is of minimum required height and design. A side wall of a pool shall not be considered a barrier. 
(c)  Permanent access from grade to aboveground pools having stationary ladders, stairs or ramps shall have not less than equal safeguard fencing and gates. 
(d)  Location or fencing required shall be subject to all other applicable ordinances. 
(e)  No fence shall be located, erected, constructed or maintained closer to a pool than three feet. 
(f)  The wall of the house or building faced to a pool may be incorporated as a portion of such fence, provided that doors and other such openings are designed to be self-closing and self-latching. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 5, 10-4-93) 
Cross reference- Fences generally, § 18-501 et seq. 
Sec. 18-621. - Electrical requirements. 
(a)  All electrical installations provided for, installed and used in conjunction with a private swimming pool shall be in conformance with the state laws and city ordinances regulating electric installations. 
(b)  If overhead floodlights or other artificial lights are used to illuminate the pool at night, such lights shall be shielded to direct light only on the pool. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 6, 10-4-93) 
Cross reference- Electrical code, § 18-256 et seq. 
Sec. 18-622. - Adverse impact prohibited. 
    No swimming pool shall be so operated or maintained as to create a nuisance, a hazard, an eyesore or otherwise to result in a substantial adverse effect on neighboring properties, or to be in any other way detrimental to public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 7, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 18-623. - Maintenance. 
    A swimming pool shall be maintained in a sanitary manner. The health inspector may inspect or cause to be inspected each private swimming pool maintained in the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 8, 10-4-93) 
Sec. 18-624. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 93-31, § 9, 10-4-93) 
Secs. 18-625-18-650. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 18-651. - Adopted by reference. 
    That a certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the 2012 International Property Maintenance Code as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the property maintenance code of the City, for the control of buildings and structures as herein provided; and each of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the International Property Maintenance Code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set forth in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-53, § 1, 12-22-97; Ord. No. 2015-13, § 1, 11-9-15) 
Sec. 18-652. - Amendments. 
    The International Property Maintenance Code is amended and revised in the following respects: 
Section [A] 101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the International Property Maintenance Code of the City of South Sioux City, Nebraska, hereinafter referred to as "this code". 
Section [A] 102.3 Application of other codes. Repairs, additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the International Building Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, International Residential Code, International Plumbing Code and NFPA 70. Nothing in this code shall be construed to cancel, modify or set aside any provisions of the South Sioux City Municipal Code or Zoning Code. 
Section [A] 103.5 Fees. The fees for activities and services performed by the department in carrying out its responsibilities under this code shall be as indicated in the following schedule. See South Sioux City Municipal Code of Ordinances for fee schedule. 
Replace Section 111 Means of Appeal with the following language: 
[A] 111.1 Application for appeal. Any person directly affected by a decision of the Code Official or a notice or order issued under this code shall have the right to appeal to the board of appeals, provided that a written application for appeal is filed within 20 days after the day the decision, notice or order was served. An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted there under have been incorrectly interpreted, the provision of this code do not fully apply, or the requirements of this code as adequately satisfied by other means. 
[A] 111.2 Membership of board. There was created and established, pursuant to Section 150.6 [20] of the South Sioux City Municipal Code, the "Rental Inspection Board", which shall act as the appeal body and to serve as the "board of appeals" under this code. Said Board shall act as a body to hear and make determination on disputes arising between the Code Official and the property owner. This Board shall also regularly review and make such recommendations, to the City Council, as the Board deems reasonable and necessary, as to the rules and regulations and schedule of fees. The Board shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. The Board shall consist of no less than five (5) board members and no more than seven (7) board members. 
[A] 111.3 Notice of meeting. The board shall meet upon notice from the Chairman, within 20 days of the filing of an appeal, or at stated periodic meetings. 
[A] 111.4 Open hearing. All hearings before the board shall be open to the public. The appellant, the appellant's representative, the Code Official and any person whose interests are affected shall be given an opportunity to be heard. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the board membership. The board shall adopt and make available to the public procedures under which a hearing will be conducted. The procedures shall not require compliance with strict rules of evidence, but shall mandate that only relevant information be received. 
[A] 111.5 Board decision. The board shall modify or reverse the decision of the Code Official only by a concurring vote of a majority of the quorum at such appeal hearing. The decision of the board shall be recorded. Copies shall be furnished to the appellant and to the Code Official. The Code Official shall take immediate action in accordance with the decision of the board. 
[A] 111.6 City Council Appeal. After an appeal decision is rendered by the appeal board, any person directly affected by the appeal decision of the board shall have the right to appeal to the City Council of South Sioux City, Nebraska, provided that a written application for appeal is filed within 20 days after the day of the decision, notice or order of the board was served. An application for appeal from the decision of the board shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted thereunder have been incorrectly interpreted, the provision of this code do not fully apply, or the requirements of this code as adequately satisfied by other means. 
[A] 111.7 Court review. After an appeal decision is rendered by the City Council, any person directly affected by the appeal decision of the City Council of South Sioux City shall have the right to appeal such decision of the City Council of South Sioux City requesting the appropriate court, as provided in Nebraska Revised Statutes, for a writ of certiorari to correct errors of law. Such application for require by the Court shall be made in the manner and time required by law following the filing of the decision in the office of the chief administrative officer. Upon appeal to the appropriate court, all fees and penalties shall be suspended until such time as the decision is rendered. 
[A] 111.8 Stays of enforcement. Appeal of notice and orders (other than Imminent Danger notices) shall stay the enforcement of the notice and order until the appeal is heard by the appeals board, City Council, or District Court, as the case may be. 
Section [A] 112.4 Failure to comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not less than amount prescribed by law. 
Section 302.4 Weeds. All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weeds or plant growth in excess of 8 inches. 
Section 304.14 Insect screens. Every door, window and other outside opening required for ventilation of habitable rooms shall be supplied with tightly fitting screens......etc. 
Section 602.3 Heat Supply. Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling units or sleeping units on terms either expressed or implied, to furnish east to the occupants thereof shall supply heat to maintain a minimum temperature of 68°F (20°C) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms and toilet rooms. 
Section 602.4 Occupiable work spaces. Indoor occupiable work spaces shall be supplied with heat to maintain a minimum temperature of 65°F (18°C) during the period the spaces are occupied. 
Section 604.2 Service. The size and usage of appliances and equipment shall serve as a basis for determining the need for additional facilities in accordance with NFPA 70. Dwelling units shall be served by a three-wire, 120/240 volt, single-phase electrical service having a minimum rating of 100 amperes. 
(Ord. No. 97-53, § 1, 12-22-97; Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2, 11-9-15)
