(Code 1975, § 8-521) 
Sec. 86-24. - Projecting signs. 
(a)  Design, construction. 
(1)  Projecting signs shall be constructed of noncombustible materials except as specified in section 8-17. 
(2)  Projecting signs shall be designed in accordance with the requirements specified in sections 8-16 and 8-17. 
(b)  Projection. 
(1)  Signs may project over public property or a legal setback line a distance determined by the clearance of the bottoms above the level of the sidewalk or grade immediately below, as set forth in table A of section 8-521. 
(2)  No sign shall project within three feet of the curbline. 
(c)  Thickness. The thickness of a projecting sign exclusive of letters and trim shall not exceed that set forth in table B of section 8-23. 
(Code 1975, § 8-522) 
Sec. 86-25. - Combination signs. 
(a)  Construction requirements. 
(1)  Combination signs shall be constructed of noncombustible materials except as specified in section 8-17. 
(2)  The individual requirements of roof, projecting and pole signs shall be applied for combination signs incorporating any or all of the requirements specified in this chapter. 
(3)  All supports of combination signs shall be placed in or upon private property and shall be securely built, constructed and erected to conform with the requirements specified in sections 8-16 and 8-17. 
(b)  Projection. Combination signs may project over public property or beyond a legal setback line as specified in section 8-24. 
(c)  Thickness. The thickness of that portion of a combination sign that projects over public property shall not exceed the maximum as specified in section 8-24. 
(Code 1975, § 8-523) 
Sec. 86-26. - Marquees. 
    Signs may be placed on, attached to, or constructed in a marquee. Such signs shall, for the purpose of determining projections, clearance, height and materials, be considered a part of and shall meet the requirements for a marquee as specified in the building code. 
(Code 1975, § 8-524) 
Sec. 86-27. - Electric signs. 
(a)  Construction materials. Electric signs shall be constructed of noncombustible materials except as specified in section 8-17. 
(b)  Enclosed shell. The enclosed shell of electric signs shall be watertight, excepting that service holes fitted with covers shall be provided into each compartment of such signs. 
(c)  Installation. Electrical equipment used in connection with display signs shall be installed in accordance with local ordinances regulating electrical installations. 
(d)  Erector's name. Every electric sign projecting over any street, alley or public place shall have painted on the surface of the sign the name of the sign erector and date of erection. Such name and date shall be of sufficient size and contrast to be readable for a reasonable distance. Failure to provide such name and date shall be grounds for rejection of the sign by the building official. 
(Code 1975, § 8-525) 
Cross reference- Electrical code, § 18-256 et seq. 
Sec. 86-28. - Temporary signs; in general, support, exception, projection, clearance. 
(a)  Size. No temporary sign shall exceed 100 square feet in area. Temporary signs of rigid material shall not exceed 24 square feet in area or six feet in height, nor shall any such sign be fastened to the ground. 
(b)  Time limitation. Temporary signs may remain in place for a period not exceeding 60 days. 
(c)  Support. Every temporary cloth sign shall be supported and attached with wire rope of three-eighths-inch minimum diameter. No strings, fiber ropes or wood slats shall be permitted for support or anchorage purposes. Cloth signs and panels shall be perforated over at least ten percent of their area to reduce wind resistance. 
(d)  Exception. Temporary cloth signs over private property not exceeding 60 square feet shall be supported and attached with wire rope that will meet the requirements of section 8-17. 
(e)  Projection. Cloth signs may extend over public property. Such signs, when extended over a public street, shall maintain a minimum clearance of 20 feet. 
(f)  Clearance. 
(1)  Cloth signs may extend across a public street only by permission of the governing body and shall be subject to all related laws and ordinances. 
(2)  Temporary signs other than cloth, when eight feet or more above the ground, may project not more than six inches over public property or beyond the legal setback line. 
(Code 1975, § 8-526) 
Sec. 86-29. - General advertising signs. 
(a)  Zones permitted. General advertising signs (on-premises signs) are permitted in business A, business B, highway business, commercial I and commercial II districts when located so that a minimum distance of 300 feet in all directions exists between signs. Off-premises advertising signs are allowed only in highway service business districts and shall be located so that a minimum distance of 600 feet in all directions exists between signs. 
(b)  Yard and setbacks. All signs shall be subject to the yard and setback standards of the zone in which located as described in the zoning ordinance of the city. The support structure for the sign shall be erected a minimum of five feet behind the setback requirements. 
(c)  Maximum display area. 
(1)  The maximum size of the display area of general advertising signs shall be 100 square feet for each face. General advertising signs cannot be stacked one on top of another or side by side. 
(2)  All general advertising signs shall comply with all the provisions of this Code and ordinances of the city and with all applicable state and federal laws. 
(d)  Special regulations. 
(1)  No portion of a general advertising sign shall be constructed to a height greater than 60 feet above the grade level of the property in which the sign is erected. 
(2)  Off-premises signs of less than 100 square feet of surface area per side shall be erected a minimum distance of ten feet from grade level to the bottom of the sign. Off-premises signs of more than 100 square feet of surface area per side shall be erected a minimum distance of 20 feet from grade level to the bottom of the sign. 
(3)  When the construction of any street or alley is modified without enlargement of the right-of-way between existing property lines so that the new curbline of the street would make an existing sign in violation of this section, the sign shall be moved to comply with this section. The city shall not be liable in damages by reason of such modification or for the cost of moving or removing a sign so affected. 
(4)  The ground area around any freestanding sign shall be kept free and clean of weeds, trash and other debris for a distance of not less than ten feet in all directions. 
(5)  No sign shall be erected or maintained on any sign or sign structure other than the principal sign for which the structure was designed or such additional single sign as may be compatible to the original design of the structure. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, convert, maintain, own or display any sign prohibited by the terms of this chapter within the city; and the terms and provisions of this chapter shall prevail in the event of any conflict between the provisions of this chapter and any ordinance of this city or in the event of any conflict between the provisions of this chapter and any other provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city other than this chapter. 
(7)  Banners, searchlights, twirling, sandwich type, sidewalk or curb signs and balloons or other air- or gas-filled figures shall only be permitted for a new business in a commercial or industrial district for a period of not more than 30 days after the opening of such new business. At no other time shall these devices be permitted. These devices will be allowed in the residential district in conjunction with an open house or model home demonstration conducted by a realtor for a period of not more than two days prior to the scheduled house showing nor more than two days after or a period of time not to exceed ten days. 
(8)  Portable or wheeled advertising devices are not allowed. This shall not be interpreted to prohibit any lettering, advertisement or identification otherwise permitted to be mounted on or painted on and incidental to the primary use of a vehicle as a delivery, service or transportation vehicle. 
(9)  Swinging signs are not allowed. 
(10)  Obsolete signs shall be removed within one year. 
(Code 1975, § 8-527; Ord. No. 96-7, § 1, 4-22-96) 
Sec. 86-30. - Area measurement. 
(a)  The area of a sign shall be measured in conformance with the regulations set forth in this chapter; however, the structure or bracing of a sign shall be omitted from measurement unless such structure or bracing is made part of the message or face of the sign. 
(b)  Where there are not more than two faces of a ground sign and where the faces are back to back, parallel or at less than a 90-degree angle, the total area of the largest face shall determine the area of the sign. 
(c)  The area of all signs with backing or a background, material or otherwise, that is part of the overall sign display shall be measured by determining the sum of the areas of each square, rectangle, triangle, portion of a circle or any combination that creates the smallest single continuous perimeter enclosing the extreme limits of the display surface or face of the sign, including all frames, backing, face plates, nonstructural trim or other component parts not otherwise used for support. 
(d)  The area of all signs without backing or a background, material or otherwise, that is a part of the overall display shall be measured by determining the sum of the areas of each square, rectangle, triangle, portion of a circle or any combination that creates the extreme limits of each word, written representation (including any series of letters), emblems or figures of similar character, including all frames, face plates, nonstructural trim or other component parts not otherwise used for support. 
(e)  The area of any sign having parts both with and without backing shall be measured by determining the total area of all squares, rectangles, triangles, portions of a circle, or any combination constituting the smallest single continuous perimeter enclosing the extreme limits of either the display surface or face of the sign, including all frames, backing face plates, nonstructural trim or other component parts not otherwise used for support for parts of the sign that have backing and each word, written representations (including any series of letters), emblems or figures of similar character, including all frames, face plates, nonstructural trim or other component parts not otherwise used for support for parts of the sign having no backing. 
(Code 1975, § 8-528) 
Sec. 86-31. - Appeal, restrictions. 
(a)  Appeal authorized. Appeal to the board of adjustment may be taken within 30 days by any person aggrieved or by an officer, department, board or bureau of the city affected by any decision the code official may make in the course of enforcing this chapter. 
(b)  Sign restrictions. 
(1)  The maximum number of signs allowed shall be increased by two for a corner site. Traffic control signs shall not be considered a sign for determining maximum number of signs. 
(2)  No wall sign or projecting sign shall project above the roof line by more than two feet, or the cornice line of the building. 
(3)  Signs shall be considered buildings for determining setback requirements. 
(Code 1975, § 8-529) 
Sec. 86-32. - Residential signs. 
(a)  The only signs allowed within residential areas and zones are those advertising lawful home occupations; political signs; and signs for the sale, rental or lease of the premises on which the sign is located. Such signs shall be subject to the regulations of subsections (b)-(h) of this section. 
(b)  All signs advertising a lawful home occupation must be attached to the residence and may not exceed two square feet in area. 
(c)  Signs for the sale, rental or lease of premises may be placed on the lot and may not exceed six square feet in area. 
(d)  Political signs (defined as those signs promoting or expressing an opinion regarding a candidate for public office or an issue to be decided by a public election) may be placed on private property only for a period commencing 45 days prior to the election and ending ten days after the election. Failure of the owner or occupant of the property on which the sign is erected to remove any political signs from his property before or after the allowable period of time shall be guilty of a misdemeanor under section 1-9. 
(e)  All political signs shall not exceed six square feet in area. 
(f)  All signs for rummage sales, garage sales, bake sales or similar activities may be erected in residential areas or zones in such size and form as may be approved by the code official. 
(g)  Signs described in this section may not be placed upon public property or right-of-way. 
(h)  Illuminated or electrical signs shall not be permitted in residential areas or zones. 
(Code 1975, § 8-530) 
Sec. 86-33. - Erection ban. 
    No new erection permits for on-premises signs or off-premises signs shall be issued by the code official for billboards or signs within the city that do not comply with the terms of this section. Existing billboards, on-premises signs and off-premises signs must comply with the requirements of section 8-15. 
(Ord. No. 96-7, § 2, 4-22-96)

Chapter 88 - SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES

Sec. 88-1. - Purpose.
new	
(a)This chapter sets forth policies and procedures applicable to small wireless facilities located within the city's zoning jurisdiction and users of the public rights-of-way. The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the development and use of small wireless facilities in a manner which both promotes the rapid deployment of small wireless facilities and preserves the safety, health, and aesthetic character of the South Sioux City community by, among other things:(1)Encouraging the placement of small wireless facilities in a manner which minimizes potential adverse effects on the community;(2)Minimizing the visual and physical impact of small wireless facilities to the extent permitted by state and federal law; and(3)Promoting the efficient modification and upgrade of existing wireless communications facilities to accommodate evolving technologies and increasing demand.(b)It is not the purpose of this chapter to, and its provisions shall not be interpreted or applied in a manner which would:(1)Prohibit or effectively prohibit the provision of wireless communications services;(2)Unreasonably discriminate among functionally equivalent wireless communications services providers; or(3)Regulate wireless communications facilities on the basis of the environmental effects of radio frequency emissions to the extent that such emissions comply with the standards established by the FCC.
If any part of this chapter is superseded, found to be invalid, or overruled by federal or state laws, rules, or regulations, then the federal and state laws, rules, or regulations operate in place of the superseded, invalid, or overruled parts of this chapter, with the remaining sections of this chapter remaining in effect to the maximum extent possible.

(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 1, 10-28-19)

Sec. 88-2. - Definitions.
new	
As used in this chapter, the following terms have the meanings set forth below, except to the extent that such definitions conflict with, or are otherwise inconsistent with, the defined terms provided in Nebraska's Small Wireless Facilities Deployment Act (R.R.S. 1943, § 86-1201 et seq.) (the "Act"), in which case the statutory definitions of the Act shall control. Undefined terms used in this chapter that are defined terms under the Act shall have the meanings provided for in the Act:

Antenna means communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic radio frequency signals used in providing wireless services.

Applicant means either:

(1)A wireless communications provider who submits an application pursuant to this chapter; or(2)A wireless communications agent who submits an application pursuant to this chapter.
Application means a request submitted by an applicant for approval for:

(1)Collocation of a small wireless facility;(2)The installation, modification, or replacement of a utility pole associated with a small wireless facility; or(3)The deployment of a new wireless support structure.
Approval authority" or "authority means:

(1)The technology director and/or assistant city manager; or(2)The city council, upon the review and recommendation of the technology director and/or assistant city manager.
Collocation or collocate means to install, mount, maintain, modify, operate, or replace a small wireless facility on or adjacent to an existing wireless support structure or utility pole.

Collocation request means an application by an applicant to install, mount, maintain, modify, operate, or replace a small wireless facility on or adjacent to an existing wireless support structure or utility pole.

Deployment means the collocation of a small wireless facility, the installation of a new structure, or the installation of other similar infrastructure by any user of the right-of-way.

FCC means the Federal Communications Commission.

Height means, with respect to any wireless support structure or utility pole, the vertical distance measured from the base of the structure at grade to the highest point of the structure including the antenna. A lightning rod, not to exceed ten feet in height, is not included within structure height.

New structure request means an application by an applicant to build a new wireless support structure or utility pole on which to install, mount, maintain, or operate a small wireless facility.

Site means the proposed location for the deployment of a small wireless facility.

Small wireless facility" or "small Cell means a wireless facility:

(1)Mounted on a structure 50 feet or less in height, including their antennas, or mounted on a structure no more than ten percent taller than other adjacent structures;(2)Each antenna associated with the deployment is no more than three cubic feet in volume; and(3)All other wireless equipment associated with the structure, whether ground-mounted or pole-mounted, is no more than 28 cubic feet in volume.
Technically feasible means that by virtue of engineering or spectrum usage, the proposed placement for a small wireless facility, or its design or site location, can be implemented without a reduction in the functionality of the small wireless facility.

Tower means any structure designed or built for the sole or primary purpose of supporting any FCC-licensed or authorized antennas and their associated facilities.

Transmission equipment means equipment that facilitates transmission for any FCC-licensed or authorized wireless communication service, including, but not limited to, radio transceivers, antennas, coaxial or fiber-optic cable, and regular and backup power supplies. The term includes equipment associated with wireless communications services including, but not limited to, private, broadcast, and public safety services, as well as unlicensed wireless services and fixed wireless services such as microwave backhaul.

Utility pole means any of the following structures to the extent the same are used, proposed to be used, modified, or replaced to support a small wireless facility: Utility poles or utility towers supporting electrical, telephone, cable, or other similar facilities; street light standards; or pedestrian light standards. Utility pole does not include transmission infrastructure owned or operated by a public power supplier or rural power supplier.

Wireless communications agent means a third party who locates new sites or provides other acquisition services on behalf of wireless communications providers.

Wireless communications facility means a structure, equipment, facility, or location designed for, intended to be used for, or used for the transmission or reception of radio frequency (RF) signals or other wireless communications or other signals for commercial communications purposes. This includes without limitation:

(1)Antennas and other transmission equipment;(2)Towers and wireless support structures; and(3)All accessory equipment.
Small wireless facilities are wireless communications facilities.

Wireless communications provider means any person or entity who provides either wireless communications services or the wireless communications facilities for providers of wireless communications services.

Wireless communications services means, without limitation, all FCC licensed back-haul and other fixed wireless services, broadcast, private, and public safety communication services, and unlicensed wireless services.

Wireless support structure means a structure such as self-supporting tower, pole, billboard, building, or other existing or proposed structure designed to support or capable of supporting a small wireless facility. For the purposes of this chapter, a utility pole is not a wireless support structure.

(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 2, 10-28-19)

Sec. 88-3. - Scope.
new	
(a)Applicability. No person may site, install, mount, maintain, modify, or operate any small wireless facility or component thereof, or similar infrastructure within the city's zoning jurisdiction or public rights-of-way, including collocations on utility poles owned, managed, or operated by the city, without first having filed an application with and received approval from the city. The city's approval of any application may be denied or withdrawn upon an applicant's failure to comply with applicable federal and state laws and regulations and the city Code of Ordinances, including without limitation, this chapter.(b)Excluded activities. Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, no application is required where the proposed activities are limited to:(1)Routine maintenance;(2)Replacement of small wireless facilities with small wireless facilities that are substantially similar in weight or windage or the same size or smaller; or(3)For the installation, placement, maintenance, operation, or replacement of microwireless facilities that are strung on cables between existing utility poles in compliance with the National Electrical Safety Code.
(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 3, 10-28-19)

Sec. 88-4. - No limitation of city's proprietary rights and interests.
new	
For all small wireless facilities to be located on city property other than right-of-way, the applicant, prior to submitting any application, must have entered into a valid license, lease, or other such agreement, as applicable, with the city. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed in any way to waive or limit the city's proprietary rights over its real and personal property. If it is determined the city has authority to exert greater rights or impose additional conditions or limitations beyond those set forth in this chapter, the city reserves the right to do so as it determines appropriate or necessary.

(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 4, 10-28-19)

Sec. 88-5. - General design and aesthetic standards within the rights-of-way.
new	
All deployments within the city's public rights-of-way must conform to the general design and aesthetic standards set forth in this section.

(1)City's right to propose alternative. With regard to the placement of a utility pole in the ROW, the city reserves the right to propose a technically feasible alternate to the location proposed in the application provided that such alternate location is within a 300-foot radius of the proposed location or within a distance that is equivalent to the width of the ROW in or on which the deployment is proposed, whichever is greater, which the applicant may use, provided:a.Applicant has the right to use the alternate location on reasonable terms and conditions consistent with the Act; andb.The alternate location is technically feasible and does not impose technical limits or additional costs.(2)Equipment. All equipment serving a deployment must be limited to such structures and equipment that are necessary, as determined by the applicant, in its sole discretion, for the operation of the deployment.(3)Lighting. Deployments may not be illuminated except as otherwise required for compliance with state or federal regulations. To the extent technically feasible, any lights associated with electronic equipment must be shielded from public view. This subsection does not prohibit deployments on streetlight poles, nor does it prohibit the installation of deployments designed to look like streetlight poles.(4)Signs. No deployment may bear any signs or advertising devices other than certifications, warning, or other information as required by federal or state law and/or regulation or by the city Code of Ordinances.(5)Security. All boxes, cases, covers, or similar enclosures associated with a deployment must be reasonably secured in a manner which prevents unauthorized access.(6)Utilities. All utilities serving a deployment should be installed underground to the maximum extent possible, provided doing so is technically feasible.(7)Antenna. If technically feasible, antennas must either be mounted to the top of the wireless support structure pole and aligned with the centerline of the wireless support structure or mounted to the side of the wireless support structure such that the vertical centerline of the antenna enclosure is parallel with the wireless support structure. If technically feasible, a side-mounted antenna must be placed at least 15 feet above ground level at its lowest point.(8)Cables and wires. External cables and wires related to deployments must not hang off the deployment. Excess cables or wires may not be spooled or otherwise visibly stored on or near the deployment except within the structure or other enclosure. New service lines must be undergrounded whenever technically feasible.(9)Alignment. If technically feasible, new deployments should be placed in alignment with existing trees and utility poles relative to the width of the ROW and equidistant between existing trees and utility poles, with a minimum of 15 feet separation from any existing tree.(10)Restrictions on placement. No deployment may impede, obstruct, or hinder public pedestrian or vehicular traffic; obstruct the legal use of a ROW by a utility provider; violate or conflict with city code or state or federal laws or regulations; or be placed in a manner that negatively affects the structural integrity of the associated support structure or utility pole. If technically feasible, a new structure should not be placed in line with the centerline of an entrance or window of a commercial building or residence.(11)Ground-mounted equipment. Outdoor ground-mounted equipment serving a deployment should be avoided to the greatest extent technically feasible, and any such equipment or structures mounted on the ground should be similar in character to adjacent deployments in the ROW and the surrounding environment.(12)Pole-mounted equipment. To the extent technically feasible, all deployments installed on utility poles should: (i) be installed to minimize impacts to the visual profile; (ii) be painted, color-blended, or coated in flat, non-reflective colors to reasonably match the utility pole; and (iii) must not unreasonably obstruct the view of vehicular or pedestrian traffic signals or road signs. In the case of existing wood utility poles, finishes of conduit shall be zinc, aluminum, or stainless steel, or colored to match those metal finishes, and equipment cabinets shall be the color of brushed aluminum.(13)New poles. If technically feasible, new utility poles installed to support deployments must be made of the same or similar material as existing utility poles in the immediate area.
(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 5, 10-28-19)

Sec. 88-6. - Additional regulations.
new	
All small wireless facilities must conform to the additional regulations set forth in this section, and the city's approval of any application shall be conditioned upon the applicant's continued compliance with these regulations.

(1)Compliance. All small wireless facilities must be constructed, operated, maintained, repaired, and removed in compliance with all applicable provisions of the zoning ordinances (for deployments outside of the right-of-way) and all other applicable federal, state, local laws. Any failure by the city to enforce compliance with any applicable laws shall not relieve any applicant of its obligations under the zoning ordinances or any other applicable law or regulation.(2)Insurance. No person may own or operate a small wireless facility within the City of South Sioux City or its extraterritorial jurisdiction without having secured, and at all times maintained, insurance coverage which conforms to the following:a.Comprehensive general liability, automobile, workers compensation, employer's liability and umbrella insurance to the satisfaction of the city to protect the city;b.For a small wireless facility in the public right-of-way or on city property, the commercial general liability insurance policy must specifically include the city and its officers, elected and appointed officials, employees, and agents as additional insureds;c.All insurance policies:1.Must be issued by an agent or representative of an insurance company licensed to do business in the state and with a best's rating of at least A; and2.Must contain an endorsement obligating the insurance company to furnish the city clerk with at least 30 days prior written notice in advance of the cancellation of the insurance; andd.Such policies cannot be modified or cancelled without 30 days prior written notice being given to the city and the insurance must be replaced by the owner of the small wireless facility up to its original amount(s).(3)Abandoned and discontinued small wireless facility. To promote the public health, safety, and welfare, the technology director and/or assistant city manager may declare a small wireless facility abandoned or discontinued when:a.The applicant notifies the technology director and/or assistant city manager that it abandoned or discontinued the applicant's use of the small wireless facility;b.The applicant fails to respond within 30 days to a written notice sent by the technology director and/or assistant city manager to the applicant which notice states the basis for the technology director and/or assistant city manager's determination that the small wireless facility has been abandoned or discontinued for a period of 90 or more days; orc.The applicant fails to respond within 30 days to a written notice sent by the technology director and/or assistant city manager to the applicant which states that approval of the applicant's application has been withdrawn due applicant's violation of the city ordinance, the terms of approval of the application, or any other applicable law or regulation.1.After the technology director and/or assistant city manager declares a small wireless facility abandoned or discontinued, the applicant shall have 90 days from the date of the declaration (or such longer time as the technology director and/or assistant city manager may approve in writing as reasonably necessary) to:i.Reactivate the use of the abandoned or discontinued small wireless facility consistent with the provisions of this chapter;ii.Transfer its rights to use the small wireless facility, subject to the provisions of this chapter, and all conditions of approval, to another person or entity that immediately commences use of the small wireless facility; oriii.Remove the small wireless facility and restore the site to a condition consistent with the then-existing surrounding area.2.If the applicant fails to act as required in subparagraph (i) above within the prescribed time period, the city council, at a duly noticed meeting of the council, may deem the small wireless facility abandoned and cause the removal of the abandoned small wireless facility, restoration of the site to a condition compliant with all applicable codes and consistent with the then-existing surrounding area, and repair of any and all damages that occurred in connection with such removal and restoration work. The city may, but shall not be obligated to, store the removed small wireless facility or any part thereof, and may use, sell, or otherwise dispose of it in any manner the city deems appropriate. The applicant, its successor-in-interest if any, and, if on private property, the real property owner will be jointly liable for all costs incurred by the city in connection with removal, restoration, repair and storage, and must promptly reimburse the city upon receipt of a written demand, including any interest on the balance owing at the maximum lawful rate. The city may, but is not obligated to, use any financial security required in connection with the granting of the application to recover its costs.(4)Remediation required. An applicant must repair, at its sole cost and expense, any damage to the ROW caused by its activities in the ROW. The applicant must restore the ROW to equal or better condition to that as existed prior to the damage pursuant to competitively neutral and reasonable requirements and specifications of the city. If the applicant fails to make the repairs that are reasonably required by the authority within 14 days after written notice, the city may undertake such repairs and charge the applicant the reasonable, documented cost of such repairs. The city shall grant an extension of up to ten days to complete such repairs if the applicant requests such extension within the original 14-day period.(5)Emergency removal or relocation. The City retains the right to cut or move any small wireless facility or poles located within the ROW, as the city may determine to be necessary, appropriate, or useful in response to any public health or safety emergency. If circumstances permit, the city will notify the wireless communications provider and provide it an opportunity to move its small wireless facility or poles prior to cutting or removing them and shall notify the wireless communications provider after cutting or removing a small wireless facility or pole.
(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 6, 10-28-19)

Sec. 88-7. - Exceptions to standards.
new	
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no small wireless facility can be used or developed contrary to any provision of federal, state, or local rule or law, including without limitation this chapter, unless an exception is authorized herein and has been granted pursuant to this section.

(1)Approval authority. The technology director and/or assistant city manager is the approval authority for all exceptions requested by an applicant. If the technology director and/or assistant city manager denies the exception request, then within seven days the applicant may submit a written request to the city council to review the request and approve or deny it.(2)Submittal requirements. A request for an exception under this section shall include:a.A written statement which (a) identifies the standard for which an exception is requested; (b) describes the proposed manner in which the application deviates from the standard; and (c) provides a thorough explanation of the technical, commercial, or other justification demonstrating the necessity of the exception requested.b.A site plan which:1.Describes the proposed small wireless facility's design and dimensions, as it would appear with and without the exception;2.Includes elevations showing all components of the small wireless facility, as it would appear with and without the exception; and3.Includes color simulations of the small wireless facility after construction demonstrating compatibility with the surrounding environment, as it would appear with and without the exception.(3)Criteria. The approval authority will consider the following in determining whether to grant an exception requested hereunder:a.Whether the exception is consistent with the purpose of the standard for which the exception is sought; andb.Whether the alternative proposed as an exception to the standard otherwise minimizes the visual impact to the Site and surrounding area to the greatest extent feasible.
(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 7, 10-28-19)

Sec. 88-8. - Action on applications.
new	
This section is intended to codify the applicable state and federal laws and/or regulations pertaining to the reasonable periods of time the city has to act on applications. To the extent this section is inconsistent with or overruled by state and federal laws and/or regulations, the applicable laws and/or regulations govern the city's obligations.

(1)Review of small wireless facility requests. If the city fails to act on an application on or before the shot clock date for the application, as defined in this section, then the application shall be deemed approved.(2)Presumptively reasonable periods of time. The following are the presumptively reasonable periods of time for action on applications in the categories set forth below:a.Review of an application to collocate a small wireless facility using an existing structure or utility pole: 60 days.b.Review of an application to deploy a small wireless facility using a new structure: 90 days.c.If a single application seeks authorization for multiple deployments, all of which fall within a category set forth in either subsection (2)a. or subsection (2)b. of this section, then the presumptively reasonable period of time for the application as a whole is equal to that for a single deployment within that category.d.If a single application seeks authorization for multiple deployments, the components of which are a mix of deployments that fall within subsection (2)a. and deployments that fall within subsection (2)b. of this section, then the presumptively reasonable period of time for the application as a whole is 90 days.e.The denial of one or more facilities in a consolidated application does not delay processing of any other facilities in the same batch.(3)Tolling period. Unless a written agreement between the applicant and the city provides otherwise, the tolling period for an application is as set forth below.a.For an initial application to deploy small wireless facilities, if the city notifies the applicant on or before the 20th day after submission that the application is materially incomplete, and clearly and specifically identifies the missing documents or information and the specific rule or regulation creating the obligation to submit such documents or information, the shot clock date calculation will restart on the date on which the applicant submits all the documents and information identified by the city to render the application complete.b.For resubmitted applications following a notice of deficiency, the tolling period will be the number of days from:1.The day after the date when the city notifies the applicant in writing that the applicant's supplemental submission was not sufficient to render the application complete and clearly and specifically identifies the missing documents or information that need to be submitted based on the city's original request; until2.The date when the applicant submits all the documents and information identified by the city to render the application complete; but3.Only if the notice is effectuated on or before the 10th day after the date when the applicant makes a supplemental submission in response to the siting authority's request.(4)Computation of deadline to act on application. The computation of the deadline to act for a siting application is determined by counting forward, beginning on the day after the date when the application was submitted, by the number of calendar days and including any pre-application period asserted by the city; provided, that if the date calculated in this manner is a legal holiday defined by the state or city, the deadline is the next business day after such date. The term "business day" means any day that is not a legal holiday as defined by the state or city.(5)Denial of application. The city may deny a proposed collocation of a small wireless facility or installation, modification, or replacement of a utility pole if the proposed deployment would:a.Materially interfere with the safe operation of traffic control equipment or the right-of-way;b.Materially interfere with sight lines or clear zones for transportation or pedestrians;c.Materially interfere with compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act or similar federal or state standards regarding pedestrian access or movement;d.Fail to comply with reasonable and nondiscriminatory spacing requirements of general application adopted by ordinance or resolution that apply to other similar infrastructure deployments in the ROW and that concern the location of ground-mounted equipment and new utility poles. Such requirements shall not prevent a small wireless facility from serving any location; ore.Fail to comply with applicable codes of general application that do not apply exclusively to wireless facilities, including but not limited to general design and aesthetic standards that are reasonable, objective, and published in advance, as adopted on or before the date applicant submits an application.(6)Documentation of reason for denial. The city will document the basis for a denial, including the specific code provisions on which the denial was based, and send the documentation to the applicant on or before the day the city denies an application. The applicant may cure the deficiencies identified by the city and resubmit the application within 30 days of the denial without paying an additional application fee. The city will approve or deny the revised application within 30 days. Any subsequent review will be limited to the deficiencies cited in the denial.(7)Scope and effect of approval. Installation, modification, or collocation for which an application is approved pursuant to this section shall be completed within one year of the later of the completion of all make-ready work or the application approval date unless a delay is caused by the lack of commercial power or communications transport facilities at the site. In such case the applicant shall have an extension of up to nine months. The city and the applicant may also agree to an additional extension. Applications for collocations on utility poles owned, managed, or operated by the city shall be processed in a manner consistent with the Act. Approval of an application authorizes the applicant to:a.Undertake the installation, modification, or collocation; andb.Subject to applicable relocation requirements and the applicant's right to terminate at any time, operate and maintain the small wireless facilities and any associated utility pole covered by the permit for a period of not less than five years, which must be renewed for equivalent durations so long as they are in compliance with the criteria set forth in Section 37(5)(j) of the Act as such criteria existed at the time the permit was granted.(8)Authority granted; no property right or other interest created. An approval by the city authorizes an applicant to undertake only certain activities in accordance with this chapter and does not create a property right or grant authority to the applicant to impinge upon the rights of others who may already have an interest in the ROW.
(Ord. No. 2019-17, § 8, 10-28-19)
 
Chapter 90 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Refuse containers and animals, § 14-11; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; weeds, litter and stagnant water, § 38-101 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 46; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 62; rubbish on highways, § 110-3; utilities, ch. 114. 
State Law reference- Garbage disposal, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 19-2101-19-2111. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage means kitchen refuse, decayed vegetables and meats, dead animals, or anything that may decompose and become offensive to the public health. 
    Rubbish or trash means discarded machinery, chips, pieces of wood, sticks, dead trees, branches, bottles, broken glass, crockery, tin cans, boxes, papers, rags, wooden ware, cans, straw, circulars, handbills, boots, shoes, hats, or any other litter or debris that is not an immediate hazard to the health of the residents of the city. 
    Waste means ashes, plaster, brick, stone, sawdust or sand. 
    Yard waste means grass and leaves. 
(Code 1975, §§ 4-301-4-303; Ord. No. 95-13, § 1(4-303.01), 2-7-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 13-2016.01. 
Sec. 90-2. - Municipal dumping grounds. 
(a)  Operation and funding. The city owns and operates the municipal dumping grounds. The governing body for the purpose of defraying the cost of the care, management and maintenance of the municipal dumping grounds may each year levy a tax not to exceed the maximum limit prescribed by state law, on the actual valuation of all real estate and personal property within the corporate limits that is subject to taxation. The revenue from the tax shall be known as the dump fund and shall remain in the custody of the city clerk. The governing body shall provide by resolution rules for the management and operation of the dumping grounds and shall set the rates to be charged for services rendered by resolution and file the rules and rates in the office of the city clerk for public inspection at any reasonable time. 
(b)  City removal of waste materials. The city may furnish and provide reasonable service to collect and remove all garbage, rubbish, trash and waste as is found in the city, which shall be collected and removed at the expense of the city. If the governing body determines to provide for the removal of garbage, rubbish, trash and waste at city expense, the collection and disposal shall be under the supervision, and at the direction of the sewer superintendent. The work of collecting and disposing of garbage, rubbish, trash and waste may be contracted by the city and the cost paid out of the funds levied and raised for general fund purposes. During the calendar year when garbage, rubbish, trash and waste is removed at city expense, the provisions of those portions of this Code requiring such removal at the expense of householders or tenants shall not apply; but tenants or householders shall be bound to observe all other duties cast upon them by the conditions of this Code. Supplementing any funds made available for administering the provisions of this section, the governing body may, by resolution, provide a schedule of monthly fees to be paid by householders or tenants for such services furnished by the city. Such fees may be billed and collected on the monthly utility service bills; and the proceeds arising from such fees shall be deposited by the city collector with the city clerk, who shall credit them to the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1975, §§ 3-601, 3-602) 
Sec. 90-3. - Dead animals. 
    All dead animals shall be immediately removed and buried by the owner of such animals; and if the owner of such animal cannot be found within two hours after discovering the animal, such animal shall be removed by and at the expense of the city. Dead animals shall not be buried within the corporate limits of the city nor within one mile thereof, nor in or above the course of groundwater that is used for drinking purposes by the city or its inhabitants. Such animals may, however, be buried in the municipal dumping ground. 
(Code 1975, § 4-307) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
Sec. 90-4. - Accumulation of manure. 
    It shall be the duty of all property owners or tenants occupying premises upon which manure of any kind accumulates to provide suitable receptacles to accumulate such matter. All such receptacles shall be emptied promptly and completely when full, and the contents shall be disposed of in a manner prescribed by the board of health. 
(Code 1975, § 4-308) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14. 
Sec. 90-5. - Hazardous items and items requiring special handling or disposal. 
(a)  No person shall put out any of the items specified below to be collected by the municipal solid waste collector for land disposal. 
(1)  Yard waste from April 1 through November 30 of each year unless such yard waste has been separated from its source and is put out for separate collection and delivery to the landfill for the purpose of soil conditioning or composting under the conditions otherwise specified. 
(2)  Lead-acid batteries. 
(3)  Waste oil. 
(4)  Waste tires in any form except tires that are nonrecyclable. Tires are not considered disposed if they meet the requirements of Neb. R.S. § 13-2039. 
(5)  Discarded household appliances. 
(6)  Unregulated hazardous wastes, except household hazardous wastes, which are exempt from the regulations under the Environmental Protection Act. 
(b)  Any such items shall be disposed of only as permitted under the Nebraska Integrated Solid Waste Management Act or any amendments thereof. (Neb. R.S. § 13-2039) 
(c)  For purposes of this section: 
(1)  Land disposal includes, but is not limited to, incineration at a landfill. 
(2)  Nonrecyclable tire means a press-on solid tire, a solid pneumatic shaped tire, or a foam pneumatic tire. (Neb. R.S. § 13-2039) 
(3)  Waste tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original intended purpose because of wear, damage, or defect. (Neb. R.S. § 13-2013.02). 
(4)  Yard waste means grass and leaves. (Neb. R.S. § 13-2016.01) 
(Ord. No. 2004-7, § 1, 2-9-04) 
Secs. 90-6-90-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 90-36. - Containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep in, on or about any dwelling, building or premises or any other place in the city, decayed vegetable or animal substance, garbage, offal or refuse matter of any kind that may be injurious to the public health or offensive to the residents of the city unless kept in metal receptacles with a five- to 20-gallon capacity and as nearly airtight as may be practical. Plastic bags and compactor bags of substantial quality and strength may be used in lieu of a metal can at the owner's discretion. 
(Code 1975, § 4-304) 
Sec. 90-37. - Unlawful disposal. 
    It shall be unlawful to throw or sweep into the streets, alleys, parks or other public grounds any dirt, paper, nails, pieces of glass, refuse, waste or rubbish of any kind. No person may permit garbage, rubbish, waste or refuse to collect; and all persons shall remove such materials from their property after being notified to do so by the city physician, who shall represent the board of health. Any person having garbage, rubbish, waste or refuse that is subject to decay or fermentation within a short period of time shall be required to place such material in a standard garbage can with a tight cover, or a durable plastic container that is securely tied at its opening or in a compactor bag tightly closed. 
(Code 1975, § 4-304) 
Sec. 90-38. - Removal from premises. 
    All persons shall have the contents of their garbage cans removed at least once a week during the months of May, June, July, August, September and October. During the remainder of the year all garbage shall be removed at least every two weeks. The governing body shall have the power to require that all garbage be removed more often than that for specific premises or for the entire city. 
(Code 1975, § 4-304) 
Sec. 90-39. - Location of containers. 
    The garbage containers required by this article shall be kept in the rear of the premises, in the basement or in passageways most accessible to the collector. If a container is not easily accessible to the collector, it shall be promptly delivered to him upon request. In no case shall any garbage container be located on the street or sidewalk except in preparation of being picked up by the collector. Such containers shall not be used for the reception of garbage by more than one family, householder, hotel, restaurant, store, wholesale business or retail business of any kind. All garbage created upon the premises shall be deposited in the garbage containers required by this article. The board of health shall have the authority to require any premises to acquire sufficient containers so that all garbage can be stored in such containers between collection. The board of health may also require that certain premises dispose of garbage in a specified manner that differs from that required for the rest of the city where the amount or type of garbage warrants. 
(Code 1975, § 4-305) 
Sec. 90-40. - Fees for removal of containers. 
    It shall be the duty of all property owners or tenants to provide approved receptacles or containers for rubbish, trash or waste. The city will collect rubbish, trash, waste or landscape waste only in receptacles provided by the city. The city will provide the initial receptacle. All property owners or tenants shall pay to the city the sum of $17.00 per month for removal of containers for collection of rubbish, trash, waste or landscape waste. Additional receptacles or carts may be obtained from the city for an additional charge of $6.50 per month. 
    The rate for removal of containers for collection of rubbish, trash, waste, or landscape waste from residences occupied by qualified senior citizens shall be the sum of $14.75 per month. 
    The reduced rate will apply only to those residences using one 60-gallon receptacle or cart provided by the city. 
    The head of household must be the responsible party on the utility account and must be at least 65 years of age. 
    The city will allow collection of rubbish, trash or waste in receptacles other than those provided by the city for one week following major holidays as designated by the city. 
    Any rubbish, trash, waste or landscape waste not in receptacles other than those provided by the city will be removed by the city one time and the owner or tenant will be notified to obtain an additional container. 
(Code 1975, § 4-306; Ord. No. 91-27, § 1, 9-3-91; Ord. No. 93-46, § 1, 12-7-93; Ord. No. 99-18, § 1(4-306), 8-9-99; Ord. No. 2002-54, § 1, 1-27-03; Ord. No. 2004-17, § 1, 5-10-04; Ord. No. 2006-15, § 1, 12-11-06; Ord. No. 2007-4, § 1, 3-12-07; Res. No. 2014-173, § 1, 11-24-14; Res. No. 2015-210, § 1, 12-14-15; Res. No. 2015-211, §§ 1-3, 12-14-15; Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 10-22-18) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Res. No. 2014-210 provided for an effective date of Jan. 1, 2016. 
Cross reference- Fee schedule, app. A 
Sec. 90-41. - Authority. 
    The governing body may provide for the collection and removal of garbage or refuse found upon any lot or land within its corporate roads, or alleys abutting such lot or land that constitutes a public nuisance. The city may require the owner, duly authorized agent, or tenant of such lot or land to remove the garbage or refuse from such lot or land and streets, roads or alleys. 
(Code 1975, § 4-309) 
Sec. 90-42. - Notice; removal. 
    Notice that removal of garbage or refuse is necessary shall be given to each owner or owner's duly authorized agent and to the tenant if any. Such notice shall be provided by personal service or by certified mail. After providing such notice, the city through its proper offices shall, in addition to other proper remedies, remove the garbage or refuse or cause it to be removed from such lot or land and streets, roads or alleys. 
(Code 1975, § 4-310) 
Sec. 90-43. - Nuisance. 
    If the city administrator declares that the accumulation of garbage or refuse upon any lot or land constitutes an immediate nuisance and hazard to public health and safety, the city shall remove the garbage or refuse, or cause it to be removed, from such lot or land within 48 hours after notice by personal service or following receipt of a certified letter in accordance with section 90-42 if such garbage or refuse has not been removed. 
(Code 1975, § 4-311) 
Sec. 90-44. - Lien. 
    Whenever a city removes any garbage or refuse or causes it to be removed from any lot or land pursuant to this article, it shall, after a hearing conducted by the governing board, assess the cost of the removal against such lot or land. 
(Code 1975, § 4-312) 
Sec. 90-45. - Construction rubble. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Construction rubble means but is not limited to lumber, pipe, wood, walls, roofs and roofing materials, broken concrete, dirt, debris and hazardous materials as defined in R.R.S. 1943, § 81-1501 et seq. 
(b)  Disposal restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or dispose of any construction rubble except in a licensed landfill within the city or within two miles of the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-41, § 1(4-310), (4-311), 10-19-93) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Sec. 90-46. - Liability for charges; proof of proper disposal. 
(a)  The governing body has separately established charges to be paid to it by each person whose premises are served by the municipal solid waste collection system. For purposes of such charges, a person's premises are deemed to be served by the municipal solid waste collection system and the owner or occupant of the premises shall be deemed served and therefore liable for the charges unless the owner or occupant proves to the governing body that: 
(1)  The premises are unoccupied; or 
(2)  The solid waste generated at the premises during the applicable billing period was lawfully collected and hauled to a permitted facility or was otherwise disposed of in conformance with all applicable laws, regulations, and ordinances. 
(b)  Proof of proper disposal during the applicable billing period may be provided by means of any of the following: 
(1)  A billing receipt or other statement from a duly permitted solid waste hauling service for collection of solid waste at the premises during the applicable billing period; 
(2)  A billing receipt or register tab from a duly permitted transfer station or disposal facility or landfill for solid waste received during the applicable billing period; or 
(3)  Such other documentation of proper disposal as may be acceptable to the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 99-10, § 1(4-315), 4-12-99) 
State Law reference- Neb. RS 13-2020. 
Secs. 90-47-90-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HAULERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

Sec. 90-76. - Contract authorized; required. 
    If the governing body does not deem it expedient nor advisable to enter into a contract for the collection of garbage and other refuse throughout the city, any person may, upon written application to the city clerk be issued a license if the person can satisfy the city clerk that he can and will comply with the provisions of this article and other laws of the city relating to health and vehicular safety. No fee shall be charged for the issuance of such license which shall entitle the recipient to haul and collect garbage and other refuse in the city until the December 31 after the date of issuance. Such license may be renewed annually if the governing body has not, in the meantime, elected to enter into a contract with a licensed collector. The application for such licenses shall be on a form provided by the city clerk, which shall require such information and documents or their copies as the governing body may deem necessary for the city clerk to determine the propriety of issuing such license. It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or collect for hire garbage or other waste materials without first procuring such license. 
(Code 1975, § 10-433) 
Sec. 90-77. - Lawful conveyance. 
    No person shall carry any garbage or other refuse matter through the streets, alleys or public ways except in some tight wagon box or bed so made, placed and loaded that none of its contents shall be spilled or strewn over, on or along such street, alley or public place. No person shall carry, cart, haul or convey any garbage in any wagon, truck or other conveyance unless watertight and cleaned with sufficient frequency as not to cause offense to the eye or nose; and the conveyance must be enclosed. The governing body may at any time by resolution, provide that all such conveyances be constructed or provided with metal bodies or beds. Each vehicle used for the conveyance of garbage or refuse shall have painted on both sides of each wagon or other conveyance the words and figures: "Garbage Hauler's Permit, number" -(giving the number of the permit), which words and figures shall be of such size that they can easily be read at a distance of 50 feet. All licensees shall in addition be subject to any other rules and regulations the governing body or the board of health may prescribe. 
(Code 1975, § 10-434) 
Chapter 94 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-11(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-11(9); any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-11(15); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; moving buildings, § 18-541 et seq.; environment, ch. 38; library, ch. 58; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 62; roadway specifications for mobile homes, § 62-33; roadway system for mobile homes, § 62-36; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 74; planning, ch. 78; signs, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 98; telecommunications, ch. 106; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110; utilities, ch. 114; vegetation, ch. 118; vehicles for hire, ch. 122; waterways, ch. 126; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Authority to remove obstructions, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-207; authority to prevent and remove encroachments, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-210; authority to open, improve, etc., streets, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-609. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - General supervision. 
    The governing body shall have the care, supervision and control of all public highways, bridges, streets, alleys, public squares and commons within the city and shall cause such property to be kept open and in repair, and free from nuisances. 
(Code 1975, § 8-101) 
Sec. 94-2. - Maintenance. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any lot abutting upon any street or avenue to keep the sidewalk space free and clear of weeds, rubbish or other obstructions; and every such owner or occupant may improve such space and cultivate it as a lawn, with grass, ornamental shrubbery and flowers that do not violate any other section of this Code. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause the destruction or injury of any such improvements by driving over the curb or otherwise. The governing body may, by ordinance or resolution, order or permit the parking or improvement for lawns, flowers or shrubbery of any other or further portions of any street or avenue that shall not be in their judgment necessarily required for actual travel; and when so improved, it shall be unlawful for any person to injure or deface the portion of the street so improved. 
(Code 1975, § 8-103) 
Sec. 94-3. - Business purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use public property for storage or business purposes of any kind or nature except as may be specifically permitted by any other section in this Code and except as allowed by special permit granted by the governing body for designated times and places, upon proper application. 
(Code 1975, § 8-104) 
Sec. 94-4. - Obstructions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or encumber, by fences, gates, buildings, structures or otherwise, any of the streets, alleys or sidewalks. It shall be the duty of an owner or occupant engaged in construction of any building or improvement upon or near the public ways and property to have all excavations or exposures of any kind protected and guarded by suitable guards or barricades by day and by warning lights at night. In the event of failure, neglect or refusal to comply with the provisions of this section, it shall be the duty of the street superintendent or any police officer to stop all work upon such buildings and improvements until such suitable guards are erected and kept. 
(Code 1975, § 8-106) 
Sec. 94-5. - Permitted obstructions. 
    Persons engaged in the erection, construction, reconstruction, wrecking or repairing a building or the construction or repair of a sidewalk along any street may occupy the public street space with such building material and equipment as long as is necessary if such persons shall make application to and receive a permit in writing from the code official to do so; however, no permit for the occupancy of the sidewalk space or a portion of the roadway of the public space adjacent to the real estate in which the building is to be constructed, erected, reconstructed, wrecked or repaired shall be granted unless the applicant meets or exceeds the following requirements: 
(1)  The obstruction will not reduce the useable width of the street to less than 18 feet. 
(2)  No portion of a street other than that directly abutting on the premises on which work is being done shall be used except with the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises abutting on such portion. 
(3)  Warning barricades and lights shall be maintained whenever necessary for the protection of pedestrians or traffic. 
(4)  If a garbage receptacle or dumpster is used during the construction, it shall contain sufficient reflective materials to warn the motoring public of the obstruction. 
(5)  Garbage receptacles or dumpsters more than ten feet in length are prohibited on asphalt streets. 
(6)  A suitable passageway for pedestrians shall be maintained within the public space including in the permit. 
(7)  Any person or entity seeking to make use of the street shall file a bond with sureties to be approved by the street superintendent to indemnify the city from any loss or damage which may be incurred by reason of such use and occupation. 
(Code 1975, § 8-107; Ord. No. 2001-18, § 1, 8-27-01) 
Sec. 94-6. - Snow removal from private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cause to be removed any snow or ice from privately owned property within the city and place or caused to be placed such snow or ice upon any street or alley within the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-9, § 1, 3-31-97) 
Cross reference- Snow emergencies, § 110-291 et seq. 
Sec. 94-7. - Acquisition of real property-Hearing required. 
    When acquiring an interest in real property by purchase or eminent domain, the city shall do so only after the governing body has authorized the acquisition by action taken in a public meeting after notice and public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 95-16, § 1(8-111), 2-7-95) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, § 18-1755. 
Sec. 94-8. - Same-Appraisal. 
    The city shall not purchase, lease-purchase or acquire for consideration real property having an estimated value of $100,000.00 or more unless an appraisal of such property has been performed by a certified real estate appraiser. 
(Ord. No. 95-17, § 1(8-112), 2-7-95) 
Sec. 94-9. - City property; sale and conveyance. 
(a)  The city may sell and convey any real or personal property owned by the city, including park land, in such manner and upon such terms and conditions as may be deemed in the best interests of the city, except that real estate owned by the city may be conveyed without consideration to the state for state armory sites or, if acquired for state armory sites, shall be conveyed in the manner strictly as provided in R.R.S. 1943, §§ 18-1001 to 18-1006. 
(b)  The power to sell and convey any real estate owned by the city, including park land, except real estate used in the operation of public utilities and except real estate for state armory sites for the use of the state as expressly provided in subsection (a) of this section, shall be exercised by ordinance directing the conveyance of such real estate and the manner and terms thereof. Notice of such sale and the terms thereof shall be published for three consecutive weeks in a legal newspaper published in or of general circulation in the city immediately after the passage and publication of such ordinance. 
(c)  If within 30 days after the passage and publication of such ordinance a remonstrance against such sale is signed by registered voters of the city equal in number to 30 percent of the registered voters of the city voting at the last regular municipal election held therein and is filed with the governing body, the property shall not then, nor within one year thereafter, be sold. If the date for filing the remonstrance falls upon a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, the signatures shall be collected within the 30-day period, but the filing shall be considered timely if filed or postmarked on or before the next business day. 
(d)  Upon the receipt of the remonstrance, the governing body, with the aid and assistance of the election commissioner or county clerk, shall determine the validity and sufficiency of signatures on the remonstrance. The governing body shall deliver the remonstrance to the election commissioner or county clerk by hand carrier, by use of law enforcement officials, or by certified mail, return receipt requested. Upon receipt of the remonstrance, the election commissioner or county clerk shall issue to the governing body a written receipt that the remonstrance is in the custody of the election commissioner or county clerk. The election commissioner or county clerk shall compare the signature of each person signing the remonstrance with the voter registration records to determine if each signer was a registered voter on or before the date on which the remonstrance was filed with the governing body. The election commissioner or county clerk shall also compare the signer's printed name, street and number or voting precinct, and municipal or post office address with the voter registration records to determine whether the signer was a registered voter. The signature and address shall be presumed to be valid only if the election commission or county clerk determines that the printed name, street and number or voting precinct, and city or post office address matches the registration records and that the registration was received on or before the date on which the remonstrance was filed with the governing body. The determinations of the election commissioner or county clerk may be rebutted by any credible evidence which the governing body finds sufficient. The express purpose of the comparison of names and addresses with the voter registration records, in addition to helping to determine the validity of the remonstrance, the sufficiency of the remonstrance, and the qualifications of the signer, shall be to prevent fraud, deception, and misrepresentation in the remonstrance process. Upon completion of the comparison of names and addresses with the voter registration records, the election commissioner or county clerk shall prepare in writing a certification under seal setting forth the name and address of each signer found not to be a registered voter and the signature page number and line number where the name is found, and if the reason for the invalidity of the signature or address is other than the nonregistration of the signer, the election commissioner or county clerk shall set forth the reason for the invalidity of the signature. If the election commissioner or county clerk determines that a signer has affixed his signature more than once to the remonstrance and that only one person is registered by that name, the election commissioner or county clerk shall prepare in writing a certification under seal setting forth the name of the duplicate signature and shall count only the earliest dated signature. The election commissioner or county clerk shall certify to the governing body the number of valid signatures necessary to constitute a valid remonstrance. The election commissioner or county clerk shall deliver the remonstrance and the certifications to the governing body within 40 days after the receipt of the remonstrance from the governing body. The delivery shall be by hand carrier, by use of law enforcement officials, or by certified mail, return receipt requested. Not more than 20 signatures on one signature page shall be counted. 
(e)  The governing body shall, within 30 days after the receipt of the remonstrance and certifications from the election commissioner or county clerk, hold a public hearing to review the remonstrance and certifications and receive testimony regarding them. The governing body shall, following the hearing, vote on whether or not the remonstrance is valid and shall uphold the remonstrance if sufficient valid signatures have been received. 
(Ord. No. 98-42, § 1, 9-14-98) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.R.S. 1943, §§ 16-201, 16-202. 
Sec. 94-10. - Requirements for public works involving architecture or engineering. 
(a)  Except as provided in division (b) of this section, the municipality shall not engage in the construction of any public works involving architecture or engineering unless the plans, specifications, and estimates have been prepared and the construction has been observed by an architect, a professional engineer, or a person under the direct supervision of an architect, professional engineer, or those under the direct supervision of an architect or professional engineer. 
(b)  Division (a) of this section shall not apply to the following activities: 
(1)  Any public works project with contemplated expenditures for the completed project that do not exceed $86,000.00; 
(2)  Any alteration, renovation, or remodeling of a building if the alteration, renovation, or remodeling does not affect architectural or engineering safety features of the building; 
(3)  Performance by the municipality of professional services for itself if the municipality appoints a municipal engineer or employs a full-time person licensed under the Engineers and Architects Regulation Act who is in responsible charge of architectural or engineering work; 
(4)  The practice of any other certified trade or legally recognized profession; 
(5)  Earthmoving and related work associated with soil and water conservation practices performed on any land owned by the municipality that is not subject to a permit from the department of natural resources; 
(6)  The work of employees and agents of the municipality performing, in accordance with other requirements of law, their customary duties in the administration and enforcement of codes, permit programs, and land use regulations and their customary duties in utility and public works construction, operation, and maintenance; 
(7)  Those services ordinarily performed by subordinates under direct supervision of a professional engineer or those commonly designated as locomotive, stationary, marine operating engineers, power plant operating engineers, or manufacturers who supervise the operation of or operate machinery or equipment or who supervise construction within their own plant; 
(8)  The construction of water wells as defined in Neb. R.S. § 46-1212, the installation of pumps and pumping equipment into water wells, and the decommissioning of water wells, unless such construction, installation, or decommissioning is required by the municipality to be designed or supervised by an engineer or unless legal requirements are imposed upon the municipality as a part of a public water supply; and 
(9)  Any other activities described in Neb. R.S. §§ 81-3449 to 81-3453. 
(Ord. No. 98-43, § 1, 9-14-98; Ord. No. 2000-34, § 1, 10-9-00; Ord. No. 2005-8, § 1, 2-15-05) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions Neb. R.R.S. 1943, §§ 81-3423, 81-3445, 81-3449(9), 81-3453(6), 81-3449-81-3453.; Neb. R.R.S. 1943, §§ 81-3449(11), 81-3453(7); Neb. R.R.S. 1943, §§ 81-3449(13), 81-3453(12); Neb. R.R.S. 1943, §§ 81-3449(14), 81-3453(13); Neb. R.R.S. 1943, § 81-3453(10); Neb. R.R.S. 1943, § 81-3453(15); Neb. R.R.S. 1943, §§ 81-3445, 81-3449(3), 81-3453(3); Neb. R.R.S. 1943, §§ 81-3449(4) and 81-3453(4). 
Sec. 94-11. - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the prohibitions or provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Unless otherwise specified in the particular article or section for which the person stands convicted of violating, the penalty for such violation shall be as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1975, § 8-701; Ord. No. 96-1, § 8, 1-22-96) 
Secs. 94-12-94-40. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

DIVISION 2. - STREET SUPERINTENDENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-121 et seq. 

Sec. 94-61. - Subject to council; duties. 
(a)  The street superintendent shall be subject to the orders of the governing body by resolution and under the immediate supervision of the city administrator. 
(b)  The street superintendent shall have general charge, direction and control over all work on the streets, sidewalks, culverts and bridges of the city except where some other official is specifically designated as the official in charge of such improvements. All employees under the charge of the superintendent shall comply with his directives. He shall perform such other duties and make such reports as the governing body may require. It shall be his duty to see that sidewalks and the sidewalk space are not unlawfully occupied. He shall report all obstructions on and any unlawful use of the sidewalks to the governing body except where the laws of the city require him to take direct action against violators of city law governing public ways and property. He shall have the authority to go upon private property at reasonable hours in the exercise of his official duties. He shall serve all notices pertaining to sidewalks, streets, alleys and other property unless some other official is specifically required to serve such notices. It shall be his duty to keep in a suitable book an accurate record of the performance of his official duties, which shall include such information as may be required by the city administrator or the governing body. 
(Code 1975, § 1-320) 
State Law reference- Duties, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-324. 
Secs. 94-62-94-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Sidewalks in subdivisions, § 98-128. 
State Law reference- Sidewalks, R.R.S. 1943, § 16-661 et seq. 

Sec. 94-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Sidewalk space means that portion of a street between curblines and adjacent property lines. 
(Code 1975, § 8-201)
